result.title: Evmos%20Grants%20Initiative
result.plaintext:
I'm starting this thread to discuss a potential proposal to set up and test a grants initiative geared at addressing 2 main challenges: 1) identifying the needs of the ecosystem and 2) sourcing, onboarding and funding projects to address these needs.

@Sheran and I had previously started a discussion about a project called the Orb . In exchanging with more members of the community, we understood that while this funding mechanism is novel and promising, the real pains involve onboarding builders and directing time and money to people and projects that could contribute to Evmos's short-term viability and long-term sustainability.

Below, we've drafted the text of a potential proposal to set up a grants initiative. You'll find details about how we envision this working for Evmos, our own motivations and how we think we can deliver value to the community. Please consider this an early version of what a decentralized grants program could be, informed by countless similar initiatives across Cosmos and Ethereum. If the community finds it to be successful or promising, we can address next steps in a subsequent proposal.

Evmos Grants Initiative

Funding the future of Evmos

Abstract

This proposal seeks to create and test a community-led mechanism for distributing grants to applicants building on Evmos, the Evmos Grants Initiative (EGI). This initiative is focused on accelerating ecosystem adoption and growth through the design and implementation of an efficient process for evaluating and financing an increasing number of grant applications.

The goal of the initiative will be to identify community needs, vet and evaluate projects and teams, distribute grants and support and follow-up with projects. We will strive to build this system with a high-level of transparency and accountability.

Motivation

Evmos is experiencing an increasing need for developers, contributors, and tools. Because Evmos is still a young chain, many of the tools that exist on other chains are not yet available on or do not currently support Evmos. Similarly, some existing tools may not be adapted to Evmos, while others still may not yet exist.

Accelerating network development to address our collective needs would no doubt benefit all stakeholders.

While many projects are supported by well-funded or profitable teams, many new projects, individual initiatives or novel approaches may require small amounts of funding to be brought to life. Moreover, a wide variety of projects, aka “public goods”, often have little to no financing or rely heavily on donations. Some of these (education initiatives, documentation work, DAO tooling etc.) are essential to a healthy and viable ecosystem.

As founders of a DAO tooling project ourselves, we confront many of these challenges. Our personal motivations to kickstart and run this initiative are rooted in our own technical, operational and administrative experiences.

Context

As of November 20th 2022, The Evmos community pool consisted of 111.49M Evmos tokens. Moreover, under the current token model, 10% of new tokens issued per epoch will be redirected to the Community Pool. At the current Evmos price of about $0.60, the community treasury is worth more than $66 million.

The Community Pool should be used to improve and build the Evmos ecosystem. Some great examples of this include the allocation of $75K Evmos to to support 5 IRL events (Prop 80); Launching Evmos liquidity incentives (Prop 64); and Evmos Developer Incentive Program Proposal (Prop 27)

Thus far, Community Pool spending has largely occurred through governance proposals. This process is extremely time consuming and requires huge coordination efforts from the community, which makes sense for large initiatives which require broad consensus.

The EGI will allow Evmos to spend the Community Pool funds more efficiently as the process would not be stiffened by bureaucracy. Through this initiative, a contributor can easily apply to receive $5K-$50K (in $EVMOS) of funding for the completion of value-added tasks which may be too small to be funded through a governance proposal.

It’s important to note that contributors will get paid in Evmos. By offering them skin in the game, successful contributors will gain from the upside their momentum creates, encouraging them to be long-term, active contributors to the ecosystem.

Approach

What makes a good grants program?

We have looked at existing programs across and beyond IBC in order to gather as much information about how existing programs work, how they are structured and how ecosystems define success.

Some of these programs include the Osmosis’s OGP grants program, The Terra Developer fund (now the Grow Juno initiative), Solana Foundation Grants, Polygon Village Grants, the RetroPGF Experiment by Optimism, the Ethereum Foundation’s EF Ecosystem Support Program, as well as donation platforms such as Gitcoin and Giveth.

While there are many approaches with varying levels of maturity and success, based on our findings, the easiest approach is to start simple. We propose 4 main objectives for the Evmos grants initiative: :

Successfully identify the ecosystem’s needs

Fund useful projects based on the ecosystem’s needs

Create a high level of transparency

Scale with ecosystem growth

We hope to implement this model and iterate upon it until we achieve an efficient way to run grants in a decentralized and transparent way that aligns with the community’s expectations. In its first batch, we propose to start with a simple solution where much of the effort will be highly manual.

Identifying Needs

The approach we put forth for running a grants initiative is above all need-driven. We intend to engage with interested members of the community to accurately identify common and acute needs in order to most effectively source and fund solutions.

As a basis for the development of this grants initiative, we have put forth a model/funnel that will inform how we build the funding process and, in time, measure the success of the initiative.

All potential solutions : include the entire universe of projects, dapps and talent on which we can rely.

Solutions we’re aware of : include the talent and projects inside and outside Evmos that we can identify as a community.

Applicants : The solutions and teams that we have sourced or that have applied for a grant.

Funded : The solutions and teams that have been approved to be funded.

Succeeded : The solutions and teams that have been successfully completed and delivered.

Delivered value : The subjective and objective value delivered to the ecosystem.

At the outset, we will dedicate the most time to formalizing steps 2 to 5, while paying active attention to step 6 in preparation for defining and measuring outcomes.

Sourcing Solutions

Some work has already been done to identify potential projects that the community is interested in funding. Notably LPX has provided an excellent starting point for this research here:

https://github.com/soulcialites/democracy-labs

https://github.com/cryptotwilight/designproposal

https://github.com/AllanM007/daoPOP

https://github.com/billzhengC/ETHGlobal-Project-Aegis

https://github.com/StableUnit/inclusive-dao-dapp

https://d3guj2x59uz7wi.cloudfront.net/DAOPad

https://github.com/orgs/DAOkeeper/repositories

https://connect.mushroom.social/

https://github.com/smart-chain-fr/FairnessDAO

https://github.com/gylim/proof-of-loyalty

https://app.opencord.xyz/

https://github.com/zenbitETH/eneagon

https://bountygranter.surge.sh/

https://github.com/pinalikefruit/UmbrellaDAO

https://github.com/TalentLayer

https://github.com/mercledao

https://github.com/zguesmi/ethbogota22

https://github.com/Trustless-ink/hackathon

https://github.com/Mbappe21/EthBogota

https://github.com/Alextnetto/private-governance

https://github.com/Granted3-0/Grantd

https://github.com/FloorGangETHNYC

https://github.com/pumpedlunch/ETHNYC-performanceFlow

https://ethereumsocialcontract.org/

In addition to leveraging the work that has already been done by @LPX , @Tricky | Cosmos Spaces and others, and in order to ensure the pertinence and quality of the grants initiative, we propose a two-pronged approach of both fielding inbound applications and outbound prospection in order to solicit projects to apply for grants.

There are 5 main initiatives we will deploy in order to accomplish this effort:

Consolidate a list of grants beneficiaries from other grants programs both inside and outside of IBC;

Run a series of workshops with community stakeholders (builders, validators, users, the foundation, etc.) each funding batch to source needs;

Hold office hours for community members that would like to discuss their precise needs;

Develop an application process ;

Assemble requests for proposals with technical or operational specifications if necessary.

We will leverage our efforts to make any information that emerges from these efforts readily available to the community including the updated list of projects seeking grants across IBC and Ethereum as well as the consolidated results of the workshops. RFPs will also be published through the same channels.

Application and Selection Process

Spontaneous Applications

The application process for spontaneous applications will be made up of 3 steps.

The first consists of a form through which a project team can enter specific details about the project, its goals, how it can contribute to the ecosystem and its funding needs. Applications will initially be reviewed by the EGI team for their relevance relative to the community’s expressed needs and seek advice from competent members in case of ambiguity.

If an application is deemed eligible for receiving a grant, the grants initiative team will interview the project team to evaluate their ability to execute and their approach to integrating with Evmos.

The grants initiative team may consult with competent members of the community when deliberating the decision to fund. Ultimately, the grants initiative team will publish the decision with a summary of the evaluation.

RFPs

Requests-for-proposals will be assembled in collaboration with community members that have expressed a similar need or interest.

A basic summary of the RFP will be posted to the grants initiative Discord channel to serve as a reference for interested teams and projects.

The grants initiative will reach out to potential parties that could potentially respond to the RFP.

Once a shortlist is assembled, a member of the grants initiative team will lead the effort to draft a more complete RFP to submit to the interested solution providers.

Some ideas for drafting the RFP collaboratively include conducting a workshop and organizing discussions with individual teams or members that may have a stake in the solution. When enough information has been assembled, the grants team will draft the RFP, submit it for review to community members who participated in its creation. After the RFP is published, the grants initiative will begin sourcing potential partners and complete steps 2 and 3 of the spontaneous application process.

Grants Decisions and Follow-up

The entire grants application and selection process will be transparent to all members as all evaluations and decisions (positive and negative) will be published on the dedicated grants Discord channel.

Grants decisions will include the name of the project, a description of the problem being solved, the details of the solution, the expected date of delivery and deployment, the funding amount, a list of the team members involved, the project details (e.g. DeWork, Treasury, etc.) and the status of the project.

A member of the grants team ( @potrok or @Sheran ) will manage the relationship with the project team in order to stay informed about the progress and report back to the community.

As the number of applications grows, we will explore ways of decentralizing the evaluation mechanism by incentivizing reviews, review audits and funding decisions.

Closing thoughts

By decentralizing the grants function in a transparent way, Evmos can ensure that the ecosystem is able to access talent and build tools quickly to serve the immediate needs of the community.

We hope that by streamlining the funding process, Evmos will be able to accelerate technical, operational and financial development of the ecosystem.

It’s important to note that while we have been studying grants programs across various blockchains communities , there is no right answer. This initiative is meant to test the viability of a grants program that resembles and draws on existing efforts.

If the EGI is successful, we can choose how to scale it. If it is not, we can decide to rethink it or kill it entirely.

Next Steps

Our objective is to launch the first batch of grants by February 28, 2023. In order to achieve this deadline, we propose 2 months (December to February depending on if/when the proposal passes) of our time to set up the infrastructure and processes. By then, we aim to have:

A dedicated channel for the EGI on the main Evmos Discord.

Initial list of grants from other chains

Build and run 2 need discovery workshops for the community

Publish a handful of initial RFP topics

Clearer references of experts and specialists within and outside of Evmos

Ideally, and time permitting, we aim to run batch 1 between March 1, 2023 and April 30, 2023. These 2 months will be dedicated to sourcing and identifying projects that respond to community needs and marketing the grants program to relevant teams and projects on IBC and Ethereum.

Our goal is to drive application volume and RFP interest.

We expect to have awarded batch 1 grants between April 30, 2023 and May 31, 2023.

Between April 30, 2023 and June 30, 2023, we will aim to set up the second batch of the EGI. We will also follow up with projects that received grants and report back to the community during this time. Additionally, we will submit a new proposal for funding a second batch during the month of May. The community can choose to continue the program as is, make changes that can be applied to the second batch or halt it entirely.

Budget

Retroactive for first 2 months: $30K in Evmos for January and February

Operational Budget: $15K in Evmos per month until June 30, 2023 (i.e. $60K total)

Marketing and Communications Budget: $15k€

Grants Budget: $250K per batch

The $250K per batch budget will be initially controlled by a ⅗ multisig composed of @potrok and @Sheran of the EGI team as well as 3 community members (e.g. @Tricky | Cosmos Spaces , @LPX , etc.). The budget will enable us to invest in promising projects and ensure their viability thanks to sufficient financing. What’s more, this budget ensures the program has enough funds to continue operating in case the price of Evmos goes down. In comparison to other L1 ecosystems, the budget and expenses proposed are fairly modest and can be revised as the initiative expands over the following months if the community deems this necessary.

From an operational perspective, we expect to spend about 75% of our time to run the grants initiative. As part of our effort to justify our expenses, we’ve looked at other grants programs across various other IBC chains in order to evaluate the costs. We found that this can vary significantly. One of the most open discussions however has been taking place on Osmosis. Given the recent renewal of the OGP grants program ( Osmosis prop 362 ) our budget is more reasonable.

We will use the marketing and communications budget for outreach across the EVM ecosystem in order to communicate opportunities to build on Evmos to developers on other chains. We intend to work notably with Gnosis Chain, an ecosystem familiar to us where much DAO tooling is already being built.

FAQ

Who is on the team?

We are a small team of 7 people building DAO tooling on EVM-compatible chains and Solana. We’ve launched a reputation protocol, Lighthouse , on these chains that offers a more intuitive and comprehensive experience than systems like SourceCred or Coordinape.

We’ve been involved in IBC and Cosmos since 2017, but have never taken an active role in this ecosystem. With the arrival of Evmos, we see huge potential in this chain specifically and hope to contribute to its success.

@potrok and @Sheran are cofounders of Lighthouse. Patrick is a UX designer, workshop designer and facilitator and three-time founder who ran a business process automation agency before creating Lighthouse with Sheran. Sheran is a self-taught developer and the former group CTO of a publicly traded company who left his job to work on DAO tooling.

We are accompanied in this initiative by 2 main advisors. Sébastien Couture of Interop Ventures and the Epicenter podcast works with us to navigate IBC. William Mougayar, chairman of the Kin Foundation and former Ethereum Foundation board member advises us on DAO tooling and ecosystem-wide needs for L1s.

What’s the motivation?

We were first exposed to public goods at EthNY in May 2022. At the hackathon there we built an EVM app called Stargaze (no relationship with the IBC chain) that distributes donations to downstream contributors of public goods based on their amount of contribution. We won some prizes from Optimisim and Superfluid. Since then, we’ve been kind of obsessed with the topic. As web2 founders in a previous life, we didn’t have to confront the same challenges. Entrepreneurs and builders that came before us had already laid the groundwork.

In crypto, and specifically on Evmos, no one’s yet laid the rails. Our goal is to make sure that the foundations of Evmos are solid, especially when at this early stage much can still evolve.

In exchanging with more members of the community, we understood that while this funding mechanism is novel and promising, the real pains involve onboarding builders and directing time and money to people and projects that could contribute to Evmos's short-term viability and long-term sustainability.\\n\\nBelow, we've drafted the text of a potential proposal to set up a grants initiative. You'll find details about how we envision this working for Evmos, our own motivations and how we think we can deliver value to the community. Please consider this an early version of what a decentralized grants program could be, informed by countless similar initiatives across Cosmos and Ethereum. If the community finds it to be successful or promising, we can address next steps in a subsequent proposal.\\n\\nEvmos Grants Initiative\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":1},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Funding the future of Evmos\\n\\nAbstract\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"This proposal seeks to create and test a community-led mechanism for distributing grants to applicants building on Evmos, the Evmos Grants Initiative (EGI). This initiative is focused on accelerating ecosystem adoption and growth through the design and implementation of an efficient process for evaluating and financing an increasing number of grant applications.\\n \\nThe goal of the initiative will be to identify community needs, vet and evaluate projects and teams, distribute grants and support and follow-up with projects. We will strive to build this system with a high-level of transparency and accountability.\\n\\nMotivation\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Evmos is experiencing an increasing need for developers, contributors, and tools. Because Evmos is still a young chain, many of the tools that exist on other chains are not yet available on or do not currently support Evmos. Similarly, some existing tools may not be adapted to Evmos, while others still may not yet exist.\\n\\nAccelerating network development to address our collective needs would no doubt benefit all stakeholders.\\n \\nWhile many projects are supported by well-funded or profitable teams, many new projects, individual initiatives or novel approaches may require small amounts of funding to be brought to life. Moreover, a wide variety of projects, aka “public goods”, often have little to no financing or rely heavily on donations. Some of these (education initiatives, documentation work, DAO tooling etc.) are essential to a healthy and viable ecosystem.\\n\\nAs founders of a DAO tooling project ourselves, we confront many of these challenges. Our personal motivations to kickstart and run this initiative are rooted in our own technical, operational and administrative experiences. \\n\\nContext\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"As of November 20th 2022, The Evmos community pool consisted of 111.49M Evmos tokens. Moreover, under the current token model, 10% of new tokens issued per epoch will be redirected to the Community Pool. At the current Evmos price of about $0.60, the community treasury is worth more than $66 million. \\n\\nThe Community Pool should be used to improve and build the Evmos ecosystem. Some great examples of this include the allocation of $75K Evmos to to support 5 IRL events (Prop 80); Launching Evmos liquidity incentives (Prop 64); and Evmos Developer Incentive Program Proposal (Prop 27)\\nThus far, Community Pool spending has largely occurred through governance proposals. This process is extremely time consuming and requires huge coordination efforts from the community, which makes sense for large initiatives which require broad consensus. \\n\\nThe EGI will allow Evmos to spend the Community Pool funds more efficiently as the process would not be stiffened by bureaucracy. Through this initiative, a contributor can easily apply to receive $5K-$50K (in $EVMOS) of funding for the completion of value-added tasks which may be too small to be funded through a governance proposal. \\n\\nIt’s important to note that contributors will get paid in Evmos. By offering them skin in the game, successful contributors will gain from the upside their momentum creates, encouraging them to be long-term, active contributors to the ecosystem.\\n\\nApproach\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"What makes a good grants program?\\n\\nWe have looked at existing programs across and beyond IBC in order to gather as much information about how existing programs work, how they are structured and how ecosystems define success. \\n\\nSome of these programs include the Osmosis’s OGP grants program, The Terra Developer fund (now the Grow Juno initiative), Solana Foundation Grants, Polygon Village Grants, the RetroPGF Experiment by Optimism, the Ethereum Foundation’s EF Ecosystem Support Program, as well as donation platforms such as Gitcoin and Giveth.\\n\\nWhile there are many approaches with varying levels of maturity and success, based on our findings, the easiest approach is to start simple. We propose 4 main objectives for the Evmos grants initiative: :\\n\\nSuccessfully identify the ecosystem’s needs\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Fund useful projects based on the ecosystem’s needs\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Create a high level of transparency\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Scale with ecosystem growth\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"\\nWe hope to implement this model and iterate upon it until we achieve an efficient way to run grants in a decentralized and transparent way that aligns with the community’s expectations. In its first batch, we propose to start with a simple solution where much of the effort will be highly manual.\\n\\nIdentifying Needs\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"The approach we put forth for running a grants initiative is above all need-driven. We intend to engage with interested members of the community to accurately identify common and acute needs in order to most effectively source and fund solutions. \\n\\nAs a basis for the development of this grants initiative, we have put forth a model/funnel that will inform how we build the funding process and, in time, measure the success of the initiative.\\n\\n\"},{\"attributes\":{\"bold\":true},\"insert\":\"All potential solutions\"},{\"insert\":\": include the entire universe of projects, dapps and talent on which we can rely.\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"attributes\":{\"bold\":true},\"insert\":\"Solutions we’re aware of\"},{\"insert\":\": include the talent and projects inside and outside Evmos that we can identify as a community.\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"attributes\":{\"bold\":true},\"insert\":\"Applicants\"},{\"insert\":\": The solutions and teams that we have sourced or that have applied for a RFPs will also be published through the same channels.\\n \\nApplication and Selection Process\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"attributes\":{\"bold\":true},\"insert\":\"Spontaneous Applications\"},{\"insert\":\"\\nThe application process for spontaneous applications will be made up of 3 steps.\\n\\nThe first consists of a form through which a project team can enter specific details about the project, its goals, how it can contribute to the ecosystem and its funding needs. Applications will initially be reviewed by the EGI team for their relevance relative to the community’s expressed needs and seek advice from competent members in case of ambiguity.\\n\\nIf an application is deemed eligible for receiving a grant, the grants initiative team will interview the project team to evaluate their ability to execute and their approach to integrating with Evmos.\\n\\nThe grants initiative team may consult with competent members of the community when deliberating the decision to fund. Ultimately, the grants initiative team will publish the decision with a summary of the evaluation.\\n\\n\"},{\"attributes\":{\"bold\":true},\"insert\":\"RFPs\"},{\"insert\":\"\\nRequests-for-proposals will be assembled in collaboration with community members that have expressed a similar need or interest.\\n\\nA basic summary of the RFP will be posted to the grants initiative Discord channel to serve as a reference for interested teams and projects.\\n\\nThe grants initiative will reach out to potential parties that could potentially respond to the RFP.\\n\\nOnce a shortlist is assembled, a member of the grants initiative team will lead the effort to draft a more complete RFP to submit to the interested solution providers. \\n\\nSome ideas for drafting the RFP collaboratively include conducting a workshop and organizing discussions with individual teams or members that may have a stake in the solution. When enough information has been assembled, the grants team will draft the RFP, submit it for review to community members who participated in its creation. After the RFP is published, the grants initiative will begin sourcing potential partners and complete steps 2 and 3 of the spontaneous application process.\\n\\nGrants Decisions and Follow-up\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"The entire grants application and selection process will be transparent to all members as all evaluations and decisions (positive and negative) will be published on the dedicated grants Discord channel.\\n\\nGrants decisions will include the name of the project, a description of the problem being solved, the details of the solution, the expected date of delivery and deployment, the funding amount, a list of the team members involved, the project details (e.g. DeWork, Treasury, etc.) and the status of the project.\\n\\nA member of the grants team (\"},{\"attributes\":{\"link\":\"/evmos/account/evmos1zyyg0fd60uwc6u277lcnk5s3d2s0m54f6d706z\"},\"insert\":\"@potrok\"},{\"insert\":\" or \"},{\"attributes\":{\"link\":\"/evmos/account/evmos1wysd8jm57wnrycnd3tqqyzx5wmwx72gwmtd924\"},\"insert\":\"@Sheran\"},{\"insert\":\") will manage the relationship with the project team in order to stay informed about the progress and report back to the community.\\n\\nAs the number of applications grows, we will explore ways of decentralizing the evaluation mechanism by incentivizing reviews, review audits and funding decisions.\\n\\nClosing thoughts\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"By decentralizing the grants function in a transparent way, Evmos can ensure that the ecosystem is able to access talent and build tools quickly to serve the immediate needs of the community.\\n\\nWe hope that by streamlining the funding process, Evmos will be able to accelerate technical, operational and financial development of the ecosystem.\\n\\nIt’s important to note that while we have been studying grants programs across various blockchains communities , there is no right answer. This initiative is meant to test the viability of a grants program that resembles and draws on existing efforts.\\n\\nIf the EGI is successful, we can choose how to scale it. If it is not, we can decide to rethink it or kill it entirely.\\n\\nNext Steps\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Our objective is to launch the first batch of grants by February 28, 2023. In order to achieve this deadline, we propose 2 months (December to February depending on if/when the proposal passes) of our time to set up the infrastructure and processes. By then, we aim to have: \\n\\nA dedicated channel for the EGI on the main Evmos Discord.\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Initial list of grants from other chains\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Build and run 2 need discovery workshops for the community \"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Publish a handful of initial RFP topics\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Clearer references of experts and specialists within and outside of Evmos\"},{\"attributes\":{\"list\":\"ordered\"},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"\\nIdeally, and time permitting, we aim to run batch 1 between March 1, 2023 and April 30, 2023. These 2 months will be dedicated to sourcing and identifying projects that respond to community needs and marketing the grants program to relevant teams and projects on IBC and Ethereum.\\n\\nOur goal is to drive application volume and RFP interest.\\n\\nWe expect to have awarded batch 1 grants between April 30, 2023 and May 31, 2023.\\n\\nBetween April 30, 2023 and June 30, 2023, we will aim to set up the second batch of the EGI. We will also follow up with projects that received grants and report back to the community during this time. Additionally, we will submit a new proposal for funding a second batch during the month of May. The community can choose to continue the program as is, make changes that can be applied to the second batch or halt it entirely.\\n\\nBudget\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Retroactive for first 2 months: $30K in Evmos for January and February\\nOperational Budget: $15K in Evmos per month until June 30, 2023 (i.e. $60K total)\\nMarketing and Communications Budget: $15k€\\nGrants Budget: $250K per batch\\n\\nThe $250K per batch budget will be initially controlled by a ⅗ multisig composed of \"},{\"attributes\":{\"link\":\"/evmos/account/evmos1zyyg0fd60uwc6u277lcnk5s3d2s0m54f6d706z\"},\"insert\":\"@potrok\"},{\"insert\":\" and \"},{\"attributes\":{\"link\":\"/evmos/account/evmos1wysd8jm57wnrycnd3tqqyzx5wmwx72gwmtd924\"},\"insert\":\"@Sheran\"},{\"insert\":\" of the EGI team as well as 3 community members (e.g. \"},{\"attributes\":{\"link\":\"/evmos/account/evmos14rsst0wnenhpxqv0drtvmz5jegp2dtcpf0srcl\"},\"insert\":\"@Tricky | Cosmos Spaces\"},{\"insert\":\", \"},{\"attributes\":{\"link\":\"/gravity-bridge/account/gravity1w2jmj6ndgraxu48hnxsmjj4en5exmcma6hj9kv\"},\"insert\":\"@LPX\"},{\"insert\":\", etc.). result.title: Common Sense Setting: No Payment For Unsolicited Services
result.plaintext:
# No Payment For Unsolicited Services

Discussion: [https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/7850-common-sense-setting-no-payment-for-unsolicited-services](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/7850-common-sense-setting-no-payment-for-unsolicited-services)

Purpose: achieve moral independence from services that are not solicited by the chain.

Do not solicit retroactive payment for services/products from the Evmos Community Treasury if those services/products and payment amounts were not agreed upon, voted on, and passed through Evmos's governance process.

This is not precluding people from giving their services to the chain, without being paid (as a volunteer).

## Exceptions

1. Force majeure situations in which the service proposal cannot be done through a normal governance process (e.g. chain halt)
2. Emergency situations (e.g. hack event)
3. This proposal does not affect services solicited by the Evmos Foundation, or Tharsis, on behalf of the chain and promises made before the chain mainnet genesis.
4. Unsolicited services rendered for the Evmos chain before this proposal, can be retroactively paid if a Community Treasury proposal is made before block 10000000.

## Author

Loredana Cirstea. Independent core contributor to Evmos and Ethermint and former volunteer. Detailed contributions for Evmos [here](https://evolve.provable.dev/).

## Exceptions

1. force majeure situations in which the service proposal cannot be done through a normal governance process (e.g. chain halt)
2. emergency situations (e.g. hack event)
3. services rendered for the Evmos chain or products used by the Evmos chain before this proposal, can be retroactively paid if a Community Treasury proposal is made before three months pass from the date this proposal is passed on-chain. Once the three-month deadline is passed, no other retroactive payment is owed by the Evmos chain.

"}

result.title: Governance Consensus: The Governance Language is English
result.plaintext:
# Governance Consensus: The Governance Language is English

## The Natural Language for the Governance of the Evmos Chain is English

Discussion: [https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/8551-governance-consensus-the-governance-language-is-english](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/8551-governance-consensus-the-governance-language-is-english)

### Purpose
Clarify the parameters for natural language on-chain Governance.

### Exposition

To achieve authority of Governance, the chain needs to establish the most accessible ground for debate and voting. The language for the process of Governance is one of the main parameters and we consider that the best language for Evmos Governance is the English language.
Since the meaning of the sentence and therefore paragraph can be changed by word meaning choice, by the punctuation signs, and by the resultant syntax tree, a consensus has to be reached on the unique arbiter for each, including the syntax tree of a proposal (in whole or in part).

### Rules
1. The accepted English dictionary for words and concepts and their semantic linking shall be the latest version of The Princeton Wordnet. http://www.lexvo.org/uwn/ with language option English (eng).
2. If concepts are not found in the source designated by point (1): Wikipedia may be used. https://en.wikipedia.org/
3. The syntax tree source shall be [http://lindat.mff.cuni.cz/services/udpipe/](http://lindat.mff.cuni.cz/services/udpipe/) with its English option.

### Meaning of the Decision

- if this proposal passes: the governance process gains additional legitimacy by recognizing prior consensus contained in the gov language itself
- if this proposal does not pass: the token holders forfeit the right to reject a proposal (on-chain or off-chain) on account of not being made in proper, verifiable English

If the proposal passes: the subsequent proposals may be challenged on:
- the natural language used
- clarifying the meaning of a specific word
- sources of truth (such as a unique dictionary)
- syntax or semantic ambiguities

### Author

Christian Tzurcanu, volunteer for The Laurel Project. Effort performed for The InterChain Pact office.

### Exposition

To achieve authority of Governance, the chain needs to establish the most accessible ground for debate and voting. The language for the process of Governance is one of the main parameters and we consider that the best language for Evmos Governance is the English language.
Since the meaning of the sentence and therefore paragraph can be changed by word meaning choice, by the punctuation signs, and by the resultant syntax tree, a consensus has to be reached on the unique arbiter for each, including the syntax tree of a proposal (in whole or in part).

### Rules
1. The accepted English dictionary for words and concepts and their semantic linking shall be the latest version of The Princeton Wordnet. http://www.lexvo.org/uwn/ with language option English (eng).
2. If concepts are not found in the source designated by point (1): Wikipedia may be used. https://en.wikipedia.org/
3. The syntax tree source shall be [http://lindat.mff.cuni.cz/services/udpipe/](http://lindat.mff.cuni.cz/services/udpipe/) with its English option.

### Meaning of Your Vote (Or Lack Thereof)
This proposal is binary:
- voting YES means support
- not voting, voting NO, NO with VETO or Abstain means that you accept other natural languages in the Governance process.

If this proposal does not pass: the token holders forfeit the moral right to reject a proposal on account of not being made in English.

- the natural language used
- clarifying the meaning of a specific word
- sources of truth (such as a unique dictionary)
- syntax or semantic ambiguities

Christian Tzurcanu, volunteer for The Laurel Project.
"}

result.title: [IDEATION] Governance Councils & Treasury Modules
result.plaintext:
Introduction :

I’m Phil, co-founder of the Govmos initiative (more on that coming later in this forum but that’s a topic for another day). with this thread I’d like to introduce the research that I made recently on the complex topic that is governance. The Cosmos ATOM 2.0 proposition introduced a very ambitious project around Treasuries & Governing Councils. In this paper I wanted to deep dive on the initial idea and see if we could build a viable socio-economic model out of these two new tools.

(I’ve been exporting images from the original PDF file, you might want to zoom on these to read properly)

(image)

(image)

(image)

(image)

(image)

Conclusion:

Thanks for reading, hope to get constructive feedback from the community. I’ll try to answer your comments as quickly as possible and update as these research topics evlves.

topic.name: 7. Meta-Governance
topic.description: This section is for discussions around governance and organizing the ecosystem, including which governance and organizational structures to implement and how.

result.title: A%20Vision%20for%20Evmos%3A%20Proven%20Independency
result.plaintext:
# A Decentralized Chain is an Independent Entity

A decentralized chain is the first artificial life that humans have created. It was created to be an independent entity, capable of making decisions with the purpose of surviving and thriving.

An independent entity:
- does not owe anything to anyone
- has a sense-making apparatus, for gathering data
- has a decision-making apparatus, for taking decisions based on available data
- has an executive apparatus, for executing approved decisions
- has a body capable of all the above, which needs to be maintained in good shape
- has dreams and aspirations concerning its existence

## Bodies

As such, we determine the following independent but intercorrelated bodies:
1. Chain Aspirations Body 
2. Decision-Making Body
3. Executive Body
4. Sense-Making Body
5. Building and Maintenance Body


### 1. Chain Aspirations Body 

Members: all who demonstrated vision for Evmos, who have strong proof that their vision was correct and beneficial for Evmos. Awarded by the Decision-Making Body after the proofs exist. High honorary title.

Responsibilities:
- set and make public the highest aspirations for the chain
- find and review proposed candidates that deserve membership in the Aspirations Body
- oversee the aligning with these aspirations of the Decision-Making Body
- oversee the enforcement of these aspirations in the Executive Body

Rights:
- the right to VETO any decision from the Decision-Making Body

Members: first members are the chain's founders. The existence of the chain is proof that they have a vision for the chain.

### 2. Decision-Making Body

Contains all those who hold $EVMOS. The more $EVMOS you hold, the higher the official position you can aspire to. 

Responsibilities:
- analyze and decide on proposals with integrity of context
- reject proposals without integrity of context
- for office holders: escrow an amount of $EVMOS directly dependent on your voting power percentage, for damage repayment of stakeholders in case your decision was proven wrong.

### 3. Executive Body

Responsibilities:
- assign and oversee the execution of decisions made by the Decision-Making Body
- implement decisions at the code level

### 4. Sense-Making Body

Responsibilities:
- ensure integrity (completeness or context) of information for any decision taken by the Decision-Making Body
- fact-checking for all information used for decision-making
- ensure transparency of the above information for stakeholders
- ensure feedback from stakeholders is registered and available to all stakeholders

### 5. Building and Maintenance Body

Responsibilities:
- keep the chain's electronic body functioning properly
- implement decisions at hardware/validator level
- implement decisions from the Executive Body



## A Dependent Chain

Anything less than independence creates and invites distrust, which leads to volatility, unfairness, and scams.

A chain cannot be decentralized if it starts with:
- dues owned to 3rd party actors
- unclarity of ownership and hierarchy of ownership
- unclarity on the amount/magnitude of funds being owned by parties involved in the chain's creation 
- unclarity of intellectual property owed


## Consequences for Evmos

Evmos should not elect members to offices unless previous dues are solved:
- [Olympus Mons Testnet](https://medium.com/evmos/announcing-olympus-mons-evmos-incentivized-testnet-46fa24270a25)
- any promises that the Evmos Foundation or Evmos team has made to any stakeholders or validators
- payments for LPX, GV, Benny Lava
- payments for moderators
- transparency on who received $EVMOS at genesis time, to be able to determine the Evmos chain dues.
- reward software that Evmos has used.
- TBD if any


## Author - Loredana Cirstea

Inspired by biology principles and Christian Tzurcanu's [work for The Laurel Project](https://github.com/the-laurel/chain-proposals/tree/main/evmos), I tried to compress and customize a vision for Evmos.

I am a volunteer, I owe allegiance to nobody. At the same time, the volunteer foundation that I am building has 1.4M $EVMOS staked.

I was elected by vote in the Evmos Interchain Pact Office [Evmos Governance proposal #45](https://www.mintscan.io/evmos/proposals/45), I have been contributing to core development for Evmos and Ethermint (code, prototypes, innovations, video demos, governance, wallet) as a volunteer from The Laurel Project (unpaid, self-funded, from the heart), with more than 100h/week. Detailed contributions [here](https://evolve.provable.dev/).

result.title: Discussion%20on%20foundation%20delegations%20and%20suggestions%20moving%20forward
result.plaintext:
Hello! Imposter Krill from Krillbucks here.

The reason for writing this post is that I wish to convey constructive criticism in a non-offensive way.

Today, we saw massive amounts of foundation delegations to select validators. First and foremost, congratulations to the chosen validators.

In this post, I will talk about two major concerns:

1) The lack of a formal procedure and protocol on how foundation delegations are executed

2) The size of foundation delegations that are being handed out

1) The lack of a formal procedure and protocol on how foundation delegations are executed

As it was mentioned in Discord, "delegations are undergoing an exploratory period and things will be rebalanced." However, without sounding too crass, delegations wouldn't have to go through an exploratory period or need rebalancing if there was a formal procedure and protocol for Foundation delegations.

Some factors the community might want to consider other than the brief criteria listed on discord are:

Size of foundation delegation based on each criteria point or in general

Duration/Expiration of foundation delegation based on each criteria point or in general

If applicable, an agreement between the select validator and foundation on some level of agreed responsibility and good faith on handling foundation delegated tokens

The ambiguity of no submission form, with contributions being made known to the Foundation through the community is alarming. This can be seen and will be seen as arbitrary decision making based on haphazardness that could be boiled down to the mood of the people in charge of handling those delegations.

Suggestion: A clear framework is necessary to protect everyone in the Evmos Ecosystem; understanding how and why things are the way they are benefits all actors involved.

There should be at least a simple and concise framework like Bitsong's delegation program ( https://github.com/bitsongofficial/delegation-program ) in place for everyone to understand how foundation delegations should be handled.

2) The size of foundation delegations that are being handed out

Today we saw delegations of 600k+ Evmos tokens distributed to a handful of select validators. 600k Evmos at this time is approximately worth 1.8 million dollars. We're talking about amounts that can shape who gets to be on the validator set and who doesn't, and at the very worst can be seen as kingmaking.

I want to clarify, I am aware that the program had the intention of making delegations. Myself and the community weren't made aware of the scope of these delegations.

I want to make it clear, I am not accusing any entity or persons of manipulating the validator set or kingmaking. I am merely bringing to light that this sets a very dangerous precedent with no transparency at hand. Delegations of this size seem troubling to the nature of decentralization.

Suggestion: I believe 600k Evmos per delegation is way too much without any proper framework, procedure, and protocol. I suggest that the 600k delegation amount be reduced somehow until a proper framework, procedure, and protocol are in place.

I hope this post will bring some discussion to the topic at hand and hopefully act as a much needed catalyst on drafting proper due diligence.

Yours truly,

Krillbucks, your friendly neighborhood krill.

result.title: [Pre-Proposal] Evmos Community Proposal Framework
result.plaintext:
## Evmos Community Proposals (ECPs)

ECPs are standardized proposals subject to voting that (once enacted) regulate and define the behavior of the Evmos DAO's Governance system, and provides a funding mechanism for special projects and workstreams.

## The Evmos Community Proposal Framework

The Evmos Community Proposal (ECP) Framework sets the guideline for all subsequent ECPs to follow. This ECP is the foundational ECP that provides the necessary templates, processes, and guidelines for working within the framework and defines the key roles required for the operation and enforcement of the ECP process.

[Full link to the draft here.](https://docs.evmos.vision/governance/proposals)

As always, feedback, concerns, ideas, are all welcome.

ECPs are standardized proposals subject to voting that (once enacted) regulate and define the behavior of the Evmos DAO's Governance system, and provides a funding mechanism for special projects and workstreams.

## The Evmos Community Proposal Framework

The Evmos Community Proposal (ECP) Framework sets the guideline for all subsequent ECPs to follow. This ECP is the foundational ECP that provides the necessary templates, processes, and guidelines for working within the framework and defines the key roles required for the operation and enforcement of the ECP process.

[Full link to the draft here.](https://docs.evmos.vision/governance/proposals)

As always, feedback, concerns, ideas, are all welcome.
"}

topic.name: 7. Meta-Governance
topic.description: This section is for discussions around governance and organizing the ecosystem, including which governance and organizational structures to implement and how.

result.title: Evmos%20DAO%20is%20officially%20recognized%20with%20Prop%2051%3A%20what%20does%20that%20mean%3F
result.plaintext:
First and foremost, a huge thank you to the: 

- 21,473 Community Members; 
- 100 Active & 200+ Inactive Validators; 
- Evmos Foundation, fellow Governance WS members, and Volunteers/Contributors for help in the passing of the Interim Constitution.

The tremendous amount of support and approval from the community (98.55% of voters), is definitely a huge motivator to work even harder and always continue to innovate and improve our relatively very new network and ecosystem.

We have a lot of work ahead of us, but it's definitely exciting! 

Priority items and initiatives that are either in the works or planned (in no particular order, copy and pasting from Twitter thread): 

- Propose an official Evmos Proposal Lifecycle as the first component of the Evmos Governance Framework 
- Propose a standardized Evmos Liquidity Incentives Program 
- Guidelines for the creation of new community workstreams & special initiatives
- Begin engaging with the community to draft and propose a Bill of Rights to amend into the Constitution 
- Keep engaging with the members of the Validators Fairness Initiative for the Validators Code of Conduct 
- Begin discussions for the Community Code of Conduct
- Propose a funding framework for DAO-initiated teams and special projects, starting with the funding for the Governance Workstream 
- Propose & begin community bounty programs 
- Continue research into better governance mechanisms fit for our network
- Creation of the DAO Treasury & propose gov components for transparency and disclosure (DAO Treasury != Community Pool) 
- Begin discussions for a Treasury Growth & Diversification Plan 
- Explore novel ideas with the community to best put our Community Pool to use
- Continue close discussions with Evmos Foundation to keep goals and objectives aligned 
- Better communication methods for governance updates for the community

A more comprehensive and detailed plan will be coming, so keep an eye out if you're interested in working with the DAO.

result.title: Meta-Meta%3A%20Basic%20Rules
result.plaintext:
# Basic Rules

## Precedence

1. [Naming And Versioning](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/6710-metameta-naming-and-versioning)
2. [Precedence Rules](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/6711-metameta-precedence-rules)

## A Note From The Initial Author

I, Christian Tzurcanu, have been working on this governance framework for several months already under the auspices of The Laurel Project and for the future governance on the Logos chain. I know that these texts may be too formal for the Evmos Community, but they constitute my volunteer effort and my sincere belief that governance needs clarity, modularity, and simplicity. And that the community will make a greater effort now to understand this design, but will benefit in the long run and (why not?) become a model of governance for the entire Cosmos.

However, I do not want to be perceived as harassing: I will continue to share and propose such work to Evmos only if the community will appreciate the benefit of having this system. So this proposal has also a voting poll besides the discussion. Maybe even an on-chain proposal for the entire eneterprise.

## Exposition

These are the rules necessary for informed governance that acknowledges prior consensus and the limitations of present infrastructure.

This is a collation proposal to name the decisions mentioned in "Precedence" as the name of this proposal. It is done for ease of use and clarity of the future proposal precedence section: instead of mentioning the 2 decisions above by name, they will be referred to by: "Basic Rules".

By having these Basic Rules, we are in the position to define, compose, enforce, and hygienically amend a Constitution.

Namely, conform to the Precedence rules number 3 and 6:
```
A Constitution for a community is the named set of rules (accepted proposals) that are required of any new proposal to be mentioned as precedence in their description.
```

## Precedence Graph

At this point, the graph should be:

![](https://i.imgur.com/swHqyBC.jpg)

result.title: [Attn: Validators] Code of Conduct Ideation
result.plaintext:
There was strong signaling in the Evmos Constitution thread regarding the need for a Validators' Code of Conduct. I felt that this topic deserved its own thread, as I am sure that there will be many differing opinions and strong disagreements. 

About a week ago on Discord, I voiced my opinions on setting a Validator Code of Conduct:

(begin copy)

"
 If a #5 validator conducted in behaviors that upsets the community, it'll be brought to attention much quicker and with more vocal outcries -- but what if a #140 validator did the same thing? No one would bat an eye.

 I'm curious to think what others think regarding this; but for the sake of trying to get the constitution passed sooner than later, I left it out. Maybe it can be amended in once there is consensus among validators regarding whats acceptable behavior and whats "crossing the line"

 But at the moment, without validator feedback on a larger scale, it's really tough for me alone to dictate or suggest whats okay and whats wrong, and how to enforce (edited)

 I strongly believe that the validator code of conduct should ultimately be decided by... the validators. Would be interesting to see 20-50 validators begin a special committee and come to an agreement. I have yet to see a validator act with malicious intent, so I am optimistic that if a committee were to be formed, the outcome would have the evmos networks' security as well as fairness and equality in mind

 If there are any validator(s) that are interested in spearheading this committee, please step up. This is an issue thats been on the table for quite some time now, but honestly all that governance can do is try to patch mini bandaids on the problem. A part of me questions if this is even a problem at all -- the top validators from what I am seeing are in the top positions because they provide a unique service or data that the community loves to consume. Not sure if that justifies punishing them; maybe it should be a motivator for other validators to step up. I certainly do see a need to address the long term compounding effect of large validators, and I know there are some proposed ideas already. Still, it's a very sensitive topic in which a single workstream or member can not dictate the future of alone"

(end of copy)

Pushing forward the Evmos Constitution

I will be pushing for the ratification of the Evmos Constitution sooner than later. If you would like a Validators' Code of Conduct to be included in it (it can also be added in the governance framework itself later on), now is the time to speak up. Especially, you, validators, but of course the entire community is welcome to input their thoughts concerns and opinions. 

To get the discussion started, let's begin defining some reoccurring terms and concepts:

1) What is "bribing" in the context of our validating community? 
2) Should validators in the bottom third of the active set be held to the same standards, or give them a pass to allow for growth?
3) Validator specific airdrops -- what's acceptable and what's not?
4) Should validator monikers only contain name and branding (i.e. no ads like 'NFTs to Delegators!' in the name)

5) Are we sure that we want to impose these kinds of blanket rules on validators? Or do we allow the free market decide. If the latter, at what point should the community or governance be able to step in and begin implementing measures? 

Validators, please speak up. Schedule meetings or Twitter spaces if you must. These are not decisions that a single workstream can make and enforce upon a huge, valuable community group in our ecosystem.

topic.name: 7. Meta-Governance
topic.description: This section is for discussions around governance and organizing the ecosystem, including which governance and organizational structures to implement and how.

result.title: [Pre-Proposal] Establishing a Perpetual Bounty Fund for the Governance Workstream
result.plaintext:
**Summary**

The governance workstream is currently operating without any type of funding and does not manage a treasury. This severely limits the workstream in its ability to effectively explore projects and initiatives aimed at strengthening the governance processes of Evmos. I am proposing the establishment of a "perpetual bounty fund" for the governance workstream.

**Abstract**

Workstreams, working groups, committees, guilds, subDAOs, etc., are normally established through a DAO or the community with specific tasks and duties in mind. A budget is also allocated to the group, for both salary/compensation as well as a working budget for bounties, special projects, and initiatives. At the moment the workstream is not prepared to receive compensation from the community pool -- _however_, a working budget would tremendously help in various ways which I will list shortly. 

Whereas EVM DAO's would allocate a working budget of X amount for a workstream to spend over a period of Y, Evmos is in a unique position to experiment with a new model. A few weeks ago, a potentially game-changing idea hit me like a train: a perpetual, self-replenishing bounty fund that is designed to minimize community spending while helping with the decentralization efforts. 

As far as I know, there are no DAOs or decentralized communities that utilize this model, nor do they have the capability. (Sample size of ~70 DAOs on Ethereum and EVMs).

**Perpetual Bounty / Working Fund**

The concept of a perpetual fund is very straightforward -- but is only available to be utilized effectively by a select few organizations. The establishment of the fund would only require a one-time spend request from the community pool.

1) The initial funds are delegated to a distributed set of validators that are in the mid-low ranking. 
2) The authz module from Cosmos SDK is utilized to re-stake a minimum "maintenance" amount (to account for decreasing APY rates)
3) Again, utilizing authz, the remainder of the rewards are sent to a workstream managed multisig wallet. 
4) The workstream will have a steady budget to work with without putting a constant strain on the community pool every X months or creating extra sell pressure. 

When compared to a normal community pool budget request, this model would A) take the initial funding amount out of the unbonded circulating supply; B) align with the community goals of striving towards more decentralization; C) provide a steady stream of a workable budget to be used responsibly and methodically (vs. a significant amount of tokens suddenly being at the workstreams disposal). 

There are obvious downsides to this model as well, such as: A) APR unpredictability and diminishing returns (hopefully offset by the increase in the token price, but that's never guaranteed);  B) authz restake and claim server maintenance and upkeep; C) AFAIK, there is no way to fully do this in a permissionless manner _yet _(ideally, the staking wallet itself should be a multisig), so there must be a level of trust given to the key holder. 

**Benefits and Use Cases**

The governance workstream would be able to utilize the perpetual fund to begin some initiatives that are currently on the backburner, such as:

Internal:

- SourceCred deployment to incentivize participation in governance, encourage constructive discussions, nurture a culture of helping others, etc.
- Incentivizing users to improve and expand the Evmos documentation
- Rewarding users for ideas that are ultimately adopted and utilized to improve governance and all Evmos related processes

External:

- Tapping into the pool of ETH developers for needed infrastructure improvements and contracts
- Utilizing tools such as Dework to fund and compensate bounties in the area of research, educational content, dev tooling, etc.
- Leveraging networks like Layer3 bounties to get more community involvement in content creation, ultimately raising tremendous amounts of social awareness

**Community Fund vs Evmos Grants**

This perpetual fund could in theory be funded by Evmos Grants, as the initial funds would not be kept liquid. However, we must consider that the foundation's resources are limited, unlike the community pool which is constantly growing. Still, a grant request was submitted to potentially start this "experimental" model of funding a workstream -- there has been no response so far.

---

I would like the community's input on the idea of a perpetual workstream fund -- concerns, questions, and additional ideas are very appreciated (and who knows, maybe even rewarded retroactively 🤷‍♂️😉).

result.title: Ban validator specific airdrops
result.plaintext:
Background:

Given recent events where the community was impacted adversely by a validator being hardslashed, and said community members where staking with this validator for a potential airdrop we propose the following changes to mitigate such risks in the future. Airdrops on Evmos are no longer permitted to target individual evmos validators. This will additionally provide a wider benefit to the community by avoiding centralization. Community will be able to enforce this as it will be possible to penalize violators using a hard/ once SDK 46 is implemented as confirmed by Jacob Gadikian.

Proposal Details:

We propose an immediate implementation of restricting airdrops to those who stake with an individual Evmos validator.

• By voting YES to this proposal you agree to an immediate implementation of restricting airdrops to those who stake with an individual Evmos validator.

• By voting NO to this proposal, you do not agree to an immediate implementation of restricting airdrops to those who stake with an individual Evmos validator.

• By voting ABSTAIN to this proposal, you agree to take no action on immediate implementation of restricting airdrops to those who stake with an individual Evmos validator.

• By voting NO WITH VETO to this proposal, you do not agree to an immediate implementation of restricting airdrops to those who stake with an individual Evmos validator and agree that deposits for this proposal will be burned from the governance ModuleAccount and the proposal information along with its deposit information will be removed from state.

result.title: Registration of Index Coop's ETH2x-FLI Leveraged Index Token as an ERC20 Representation
result.plaintext:
**About Index Coop**: The Index Cooperative aka Index Coop builds simple yet powerful tokens which help DeFi users access sophisticated crypto strategies. Established in 2020, Index Coop is an [open source](https://github.com/IndexCoop) protocol at the forefront of DeFi innovation and is known for its success in index products such as the Defi Pulse Index (DPI) token, Metaverse Index (MVI), and its range of Interest Compounding and 2x Flexible Leverage Index tokens.

**About ETH 2x Flexible Leverage Index (ETH2x-FLI)**: The ETH 2x Flexible Leverage Index abstracts collateralized debt management into a simple index, reproducible by an ERC20 token built on Set Protocol. ETH2x-FLI enables you to get leveraged exposure to Ether using collateralized debt, without having to manage collateralized debt positions or monitor liquidation risks. More information on Index Coop's FLI can be read [here](https://indexcoop.com/ethereum-flexible-leverage-index-eth2xfli) and [here](https://medium.com/indexcoop/introducing-the-flexible-leverage-index-fli-by-pulse-inc-a369bd422ef).

result.title: Registering%20CMDX%20and%20CMST%20as%20ERC20
result.plaintext:
Comdex is looking forward to collaborating with the Evmos community and would like to propose registering $CMDX and $CMST as ERC-20 tokens on Evmos. When a proposal is initiated for an existing native Cosmos Coin, the ERC20 module will deploy a factory ERC20 contract representing the ERC20 token for the token pair. This enables access to DeFi protocols, NFT, and new applications that are based on ERC-20 (like AAVE, Diffusion, etc.)

Background

Comdex is building a DeFi infrastructure layer for the Cosmos ecosystem. A layer-1 infrastructure system for seamless deployment of DeFi applications in the Cosmos ecosystem, powering DeFi in the multi-chain future.

The core set of dApps on the chain will help form the foundation layer of money markets for Cosmos, namely:

Harbor protocol: Interchain Stablecoin Issuance Protocol for $CMST (overcollateralized stablecoin)

cSwap DEX: Hybrid Orderbook-style AMM DEX

Commodo: Interchain liquidity protocol for lending-borrowing

These dApps form the foundational blocks of composable DeFi "Legos," which will ultimately help users have democratized access to interchain money markets to ultimately integrate off-chain CeFi assets into the ecosystem.

The Harbor Protocol and cSwap are now live on the mainnet, and we're looking forward to potential partnership opportunities and exploring synergies between the Evmos and Comdex ecosystems.

CMST would serve as a native decentralized stablecoin for the Evmos ecosystem. To encourage adoption, the Harbor token is being airdropped to the Evmos community. This would enable the Evmos community to participate in Harbor governance.

Potential benefits for the Evmos ecosystem would be the minting of CMST using the Evmos token vaults once it goes live. This would enable stable token borrowing using Evmos as collateral to provide broader use cases for the Evmos token in the Comdex DeFi ecosystem.

result.title: Questions about registering a custom ERC20 as a cosmos coin
result.plaintext:
We are building a legal and technical framework to incorporate legal DAOs in Estonia.

Our ERC-20 has some specific properties that only apply to a subset KYC'd holders, like voting rights, access to dividends, and pre-emption right. Non KYC'd holders lose these rights, but they can trade and speculate the token in the secondary market. (Happy to share more details about it, if you are curious you can check our application to the Momentum Hackathon here https://devpost.com/software/teledisko-dao)

We mint new tokens each month to reward our contributors for their work. The minting is not arbitrary but it follow some rules, and it's reviewed and [approved by the DAO](https://dao.teledisko.com/#/resolutions/9).

We created a custom ERC-20 based on the OpenZeppelin implementation. The rules I described before make the source code of our token quite meaty. This is our current implementation: [TelediskoToken.sol](https://github.com/TelediskoDAO/contracts/blob/v1.0.0/contracts/TelediskoToken/TelediskoToken.sol).

We would like to understand how much effort it would be to register it as a "cosmos coin".

_Important: we don't want to register **this specific token** (we are still experimenting with the tokenomics). We would like to understand how much effort it would be to register **a token like this one** as a cosmos coin._

We went through the [documentation](https://github.com/evmos/evmos/blob/v10.0.0-rc1/x/erc20/spec/03_state_transitions.md#2-register-erc20) and we are aware that custom contracts can hide [malicious behavior](https://github.com/evmos/evmos/blob/v10.0.0-rc1/x/erc20/spec/01_concepts.md#malicious-contracts): for this reason to make the reviewing process smoother the contract should be verified on an explorer, and audited by a reputable third party (we will audit the contract before opening our token to external investors).

Let's say we want to register our token as a coin by submitting a `RegisterERC20Proposal` to the EVMOS Governance. Let's also say that our token has been audited (not true **yet**, but bear with me). If we submit such proposal, how would you react? Do you see any red flags?

We would love to get feedback from the EVMOS community. We are asking this early so we can adapt our development to the requirements of the community.

result.title: Registration%20of%20Tgrade's%20TGD%20asset%20as%20an%20ERC20%20Representation
result.plaintext:
We propose an ERC20 representation for TGD.

Tgrade [https://tgrade.finance](https://tgrade.finance) is a blockchain project built by Confio, makers of CosmWasm. Tgrade is a Cosmos-compatible chain with its own CosmWasm engine and a novel consensus mechanism called Proof of Engagement which has been designed to incentivize collaboration. Tgrade has been designed from the ground up to be decentralized, and secure in order to support regulated financial businesses. Tgrade has an on-chain governance system that allows for the creation and maintenance of permissioned groups, named Trusted Circles, each with its own governance and rules.

Proposal: The Laurel Project (evmos4volunteers) will make an on-chain proposal to register TGD as an ERC-20 token on Evmos. Once the proposal is approved by the EVMOS governance, the ERC-20 uses a factory pattern to deploy an ERC20 token contract representation of the TGD coin. More info regarding the x/erc20 module [here](https://medium.com/evmos/introducing-evmos-erc20-module-f40a61e05273). 

Main benefits: 
- Users will be able to swap EVMOS <-> TGD on Evmos. 
- Evmos will have access to DeFi protocols build with CosmWasm, on Tgrade and Tgrade will have access to Evmos DeFi.
- Tgrade is business-focused and builds a chain compatible with EU regulations while still remaining decentralized. 

JSON:
```
{
 "description": "The native staking and governance token of the Tgrade chain",
  "denom_units": [
        {
            "denom": "ibc/46AB1362B4446BCE0FD7D2F247FFCA8CC39BC6CA7AEAD03C77CABBD1CB41E5C9",
            "exponent": 0,
            "aliases": ["utgd"]
        },
        {
            "denom": "TGD",
            "exponent": 6
        }

    ],
    "base": "ibc/46AB1362B4446BCE0FD7D2F247FFCA8CC39BC6CA7AEAD03C77CABBD1CB41E5C9",
    "display": "TGD",
    "name": "Tgrade",
    "symbol": "TGD"
}
```

version_history: {"timestamp":"2022-10-29T22:23:27.210Z","author":"{\"_judgements\":{},\"_isOnchain\":false,\"_isCouncillor\":false,\"_isValidator\":false,\"_isEmpty\":false,\"_isNameInvalid\":false,\"chain\":\"evmos\",\"address\":\"evmos1kcefmk8x3hkke9ea0vwnpxxvf7knskx67kvwsf\",\"_initialized\":true,\"_name\":\"Epicdylan.evmos\",\"_headline\":\"PageDAO Founder\",\"_bio\":\"https://dylan.cent.co / https://page.cent.co\",\"_lastActive\":\"2022-10-28T19:58:25.348Z\"}","body":"{\"ops\":[{\"insert\":\"Hi Evmos community. It is good to be posting here! I am getting ready to launch ERC-20 token $PAGE (bridged via Gravity Bridge) into Evmos as an ERC-20 token. More information about PageDAO can be found at https://pagedao.org. At this point, we need to be sure that the json is correct. In my mind the main question that remains is the exponent of 8; which we have done to attempt to match the Ethereum token (it has 8 decimal places). As long as that is correct, I believe we should be good to go!\\n\\nOur one sentence description: What is Page: Page is a cryptocurrency built with the needs of writers in mind, designed to incentivize the growth of open source publishing technology for Web3 environments.\\n\\nHere is our bridge txn data: \\n\\n{\\\"key\\\":\\\"denom\\\",\\\"value\\\":\\\"ibc/E1136B918D1D8CD8ADAA7C6B73A98588AE28F2A3E1F89FD2DC4E5FB7D8CA1E82\\\"}\\n\\nAnd here is updated JSON with $PAGE's info: \\n\\n{\\n \\\"description\\\": \\\"The writer's cryptocurrency\\\",\\n  \\\"denom_units\\\": [\\n        {\\n            \\\"denom\\\": \\\"ibc/E1136B918D1D8CD8ADAA7C6B73A98588AE28F2A3E1F89FD2DC4E5FB7D8CA1E82\\\",\\n            \\\"exponent\\\": 0,\\n            \\\"aliases\\\": [\\\"upage\\\"]\\n        },\\n        {\\n            \\\"denom\\\": \\\"page\\\",\\n            \\\"exponent\\\": 8\\n        }\\n\\n    ],\\n    \\\"base\\\": \\\"ibc/E1136B918D1D8CD8ADAA7C6B73A98588AE28F2A3E1F89FD2DC4E5FB7D8CA1E82\\\",\\n    \\\"display\\\": \\\"Page\\\",\\n    \\\"name\\\": \\\"Page\\\",\\n    \\\"symbol\\\": \\\"PAGE\\\"\\n} \\n\\n\"}]}"}

result.title: This proposal creates and registers an ERC-20 representation for Injective (INJ)
result.plaintext:
Hello!

What is INJ: Injective  is an open interoperable smart contracts layer-one blockchain network optimized for decentralized finance applications. They recently raised $40M From Jump Crypto, Brevan Howard Unit.

Proposal: Proposal: We at Swiss Staking will make a proposal to register INJ as an ERC-20 token on Evmos. Once the proposal is approved by the EVMOS governance, the ERC-20 uses a factory pattern to deploy an ERC20 token contract representation of the INJ coin. More info regarding x/erc20 module here. Main benefits for doing so: Users will be able to swap Evmos with INJ on Evmos itself (giving INJ access to DeFi protocols, NFT). Build new applications that are based on ERC-20 smart contracts and have access to the Cosmos ecosystem.

JSON draft:

{  "description": "The INJ token is the native governance token for the Injective chain.",   "denom_units": [         {             "denom": "ibc/ADF401C952ADD9EE232D52C8303B8BE17FE7953C8D420F20769AF77240BD0C58",             "exponent": 0,             "aliases": ["inj"]         },            {             "denom": "INJ",             "exponent": 18            }     ],     "base": "ibc/ADF401C952ADD9EE232D52C8303B8BE17FE7953C8D420F20769AF77240BD0C58",     "display": "INJ",     "name": "Injective",     "symbol": "INJ" }

result.title: This%20proposal%20creates%20and%20registers%20an%20ERC-20%20representation%20for%20Teritori%20(TORI)
result.plaintext:
Hello!

The Teritori team reached out for the ERC-20 representation. 

What is TORI: Teritori is built to enhance Web3 individuals, communities & builders experience through an all-in-one hub of dApps.

Proposal: We at Swiss Staking will make a proposal to register TORI as an ERC-20 token on Evmos. Once the proposal is approved by the EVMOS governance, the ERC-20 uses a factory pattern to deploy an ERC20 token contract representation of the TORI coin. More info regarding x/erc20 module here. Main benefits for doing so:
Users will be able to swap Evmos with TORI on Evmos itself (giving TORI access to DeFi protocols, NFT).
Build new applications that are based on ERC-20 smart contracts and have access to the Cosmos ecosystem

result.title: This proposal creates and registers an ERC-20 representation for Kujiras USD stablecoin (USK)
result.plaintext:
Hey Hey Hey

More stablecoins coming to Evmos!

**What is USK:**
Kujira $USK is a native Cosmos overcollateralized stablecoin soft-pegged to the US dollar, initially backed by $ATOM. Users stake collateral to mint $USK while users would burn $USK to redeem their collateral.

**Proposal:**
We at Swiss Staking will make a proposal next week to register Kujira's stablecoin (USK) as an ERC-20 token on Evmos. Once the proposal is approved by the EVMOS governance, the ERC-20 uses a factory pattern to deploy an ERC20 token contract representation of the USK stablecoin. More info regarding x/erc20 module here.
Main benefits for doing so:
- Users will be able to swap Evmos with USK on Evmos itself (giving USK access to DeFi protocols, NFT).
- Build new applications that are based on ERC-20 smart contracts and have access to the Cosmos ecosystem

result.title: Registration%20for%20Stride%20assets%20STRD%2C%20stATOM%2C%20stJUNO%2C%20stOSMO%2C%20and%20stSTARS%20ERC20%20Representations.
result.plaintext:
Overview

This thread is beginning the process to enable the creation of ERC20 representations for the upcoming liquid staking chain Stride and its DeFi assets. This will allow these Cosmos native assets to be converted into an ERC20 representation to be fully utilized on the Evmos chain in things such as DeFi.

Tokens To Be Registered:

STRD: The native staking and governance token of the Stride chain

stATOM: The Stride liquid staking derivative of the ATOM token

stJUNO: The Stride liquid staking derivative of the JUNO token

stOSMO: The Stride liquid staking derivative of the OSMO token

stSTARS: The Stride liquid staking derivative of the STARS token

Benefits:

Liquid staked assets unlock a large amount of liquidity to be used in DeFi. Having these assets on Evmos will help spark DeFi, improve TVL, and bring in users from multiple ecosystems by enabling exposure to DeFi protocols.

The JSON for the proposal will be made by the guru himself, @GV | Swiss Staking  .

Please provide any feedback or concerns if there is anything needs to be addressed before going on chain.

result.title: Registration of QCK, qATOM, qJUNO, qOSMO, and qSTARS ERC20 Representations
result.plaintext:
Overview

This thread is beginning the process to enable the creation of ERC20 representations for the upcoming Cosmos chain Quicksilver and its DeFi assets. This will allow these Cosmos native assets to be converted into an ERC20 representation to be fully utilized on the Evmos chain in things such as DeFi.

Tokens To Be Registered:

QCK: The native staking and governance token of the Quicksilver chain

qATOM: The quicksilver liquid staking derivative of the ATOM token

qJUNO: The quicksilver liquid staking derivative of the JUNO token

qOSMO: The quicksilver liquid staking derivative of the OSMO token

qSTARS: The quicksilver liquid staking derivative of the STARS token

Benefits:

Liquid staked assets unlock a large amount of liquidity to be used in DeFi. Having these assets on Evmos will help spark DeFi, improve TVL, and bring in users from multiple ecosystems by enabling exposure to DeFi protocols.

The JSON for the proposal will be made by the guru himself, @GV | Swiss Staking .

Please provide any feedback or concerns if there is anything needs to be addressed before going on chain.
