result.title: Follow%20up%20-%20Sponsor%20Loredana%20as%20a%20volunteer%20researcher%20for%20EVM%20Interchain%20lobby%20for%20Evmos
result.plaintext:
Hi all!

The purpose of this discussion is to gauge community sentiment on the continuation of the EVM interchain lobbying sponsorship for @Loredana , established with Proposal 45 . We are nearing the end of the first 3 month term (Jan. 7th), so I felt it was an appropriate time to revisit this sponsorship!

The original commonwealth discussion can be found HERE

Background

With the passing of Proposal 45, the Evmos community approved a 3 month sponsorship of Loredana's rent (apartment + office) in Berlin. Effectively sponsoring her EVM interchain lobbying services, for the benefit of Evmos. Sponsorship is paid 3 months in advance, every 3 months until the community decides to stop it. A total of 12,000 EVMOS was allocated for this effort for the first 6 months, to give the community a chance to re-vote based on output.

Output & Deliverables

At the end of each month, a detailed list of output will be posted to Github .

Summary of output to date:

(image)

Expenses

6000 out of the total 12,000 EVMOS were transferred out of the multisig for the first 3 months of sponsorship (Oct. 7th - Jan. 7th). The list of expenses can also be found on Github .

Summary of expenses to date:

(image)

Let's discuss how @Loredana 's interchain lobbying services have benefitted Evmos and whether we should continue this sponsorship for another 3 months!

result.title: Govmos Initiative Leaving - Our "post-mortem" analysis
result.plaintext: We have recently decided to put thing in a hold on our initiative. The journey into evmos governance has been painful & very disturbing. We acknowledge that our entry at the discussion table has been inappropriate, but the situation here is very concerning as well. That's part of the reason why we decided to take a step back and assess because we have made some mistakes. We thought we owed everyone a kind of "post-mortem" analysis of that decision : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FuAmK5gOnk8

result.title: Signaling Proposal - Amend the Mars Meteor Mission Incentives
result.plaintext:
As detailed in this article, the testnet incentives outlined here proposed to allocate 16,922,500 EVMOS for testnet participants, with the percentage of tokens to be distributed dependent of testnet participants.

(image)

As stated in this image, the exact brackets are subject to change. Unfortunately, the participation brackets were not updated and that led to some participants to believe that those that voted once on testnet (5 points), would be getting 2500 evmos for their efforts (500 evmos per point). To solve this, I propose we amend this by setting the 25% threshold to the total participants in testnet (2,054), this would result in 125 evmos per point for testnet participation.

If this change was implemented, participants that voted once (5 pts) will receive a still generous 600 evmos, while more active participants with 100 points or more will receive from 12,500 evmos, up to 54,375 evmos for the top participant (435 points).

Open to input for the community since this will help participants be clear on their future rewards. I acknowledge I may be wrong on this so I would like community participation/opinion on this, outside of those that are aware of olympus-mons.

Would like to have this on chain on monday so there is time for vote before the holidays.

Here is the final results table for reference: https://mzonder.com/evmos/olympus-mons/

result.title: high%20inflation%20is%20basically%20a%20Ponzi%20Scheme%2C%20lets%20disccus%20what%20we%20can%20do%20to%20help%20this%20ponzi%20keep%20running
result.plaintext:
lets admit it!

High APR are just ponzi schemes, there are always death sprital when a little snow ball start to rolling from the top mountains.

Even High APR Stable coins can't hold its pegg and depegging at a certain time, such as UST and USDN.

i do not think dev team will end this High APR soon or later, if we keep this high apr running, we will only have hope that things will turn to the north after 4th halving or tokens are released to close 1 billion.

OR there are really GREAT projects that able to locking most of these inflations. this might be the solution, we have to aggresively look around the crypto world and find what projects are outstanding in their field and let them come!!!!

we should ultilize community pool or other avaliable fund source to attract those devs, we should not letting funds sitting there and lose its values.

even we might eventually managed to attracted those devs, but but, due to the high APR ,we won't convincing majority of the people who holds EVMOS providing liquidity to those projects as staking rewards are high enough.

guys, whats your thoughts? lets give some brainstorm!!!

i love EVMOS!!!!

result.title: Temperature%20Check%20-%20Limit%20Voting%20Power
result.plaintext:
EVMOS started and praised itself to be 100% community funded.

The fact that it wasn't involved with any initial VC funding was used as marketing throughout most of EVMOS initial days and it was certainly something to brag about as Evmos was a community effort that came out of an Atom Proposal.

The implications of not being VC funded were that Evmos was in the hand of the community when it came to major decisions through proposals. As it stands now, 23.3% of the voting power in EVMOS is controlled by VC validators who participated in the latest EVMOS Foundation funding round. This may not be the case, but if these validators act like other VC's in other Cosmos chains, then we can assume we won't count with their vote/participation in upcoming proposals. With this, we are taking away voting power from the community and the users of evmos, and putting it away in validators that don't engage in governance and may or may not vote.

Thankfully, we are still early to address this, and a method to prevent voting power from escaping the community would be to implement a voting power cap, which sets a hard limit on how much more voting power can go to these validators.

While it's true that VC's can simply run two nodes and place their excess voting power there, they could also delegate to smaller validators and help decentralization as a sign of supporting the community that builds and uses EVMOS. It would be a small hit of a 5% commission on the excess of their stake, but it would be a strong signal that they trust the community of the chain they invested in. If they decide to start another validator, then it will give us a preview of how they'll behave in the future.

A Voting Power cap is not something unheard of, and has been implemented in other Cosmos chains, and it works. By doing this on Evmos, we can shift the power back to the community and prevent it from completely escaping it to a point where a proposal like this couldn't pass.

The purpose of this proposal is to understand if the community supports the implementation of a cap on validator's voting power.

If there is enough support to this simple idea we can move forward into specifics on like what should the percentage cap be, how should it be implemented and by whom.

result.title: Nasty%20nasty%20decay
result.plaintext:
Just found out I would have had 350 evmos to claim in an older wallet that I have not been using for a long time. Imported my Metamask address on the rektdrop page, just to find out: it is all gone. This sucks. This has been such a troubled year, even tax authorities around the world extend their deadlines, and here we have a 2 month decay? Seriously? That's bullshit. It has literally become a REKTdrop, muchas gracias!!!!!!

This is not some shitcoin airdrop across every wallet on the blockchain. Every user who was entitled to free EVMOS had some skin in the game and there were active wallet addresses behind each, so why was this not automatically airdropped to the wallets in question? Instead of creating a destructive decay mechanism?

At least the period should have been extended by years, not months. Persistence is what I like most about crypto. If I don´t have contact with my bank for awhile, the account will become dormant and at some point, the account and the money will be gone. Not so with crypto. Even after years of dormancy, the funds are still on the private key, as long as the blockchain exists.

This decay is a nasty thing to do, and so I am asking the question: how realistic is a proposal to remedy the situation? For instance: everyone who would have had an EVMOS airdrop claim, will receive their decayed funds retroactively, without further activity needed from the user side? This could be achieved by an automatic process running at a given date, e.g. end of 2022, or by a permanent link on the dashboard. To keep things simple, entering an address (cosmos or evmos) and hitting "claim" should be enough. So no need to maintain a complicated rektdrop dashboard over the long term.

Currently, the unclaimed funds will be returned to the community wallet, but for what purpose? Pissing off users who missed the deadline, are much less likely to use the project in the future. This will cause more loss of value to the token, than the returned funds will be worth.

result.title: Unite%20and%20Support%3A%20Defending%20the%20Governance%20Council%20and%20Denouncing%20Phil's%20Dangerous%20Ideas
result.plaintext:
I'm too old to be spending energy on publicly shaming everyone for shit like this, but I felt the need to defend the "Governance Council" after lurking for months and being amused at all the shit that unfolds in Cosmos. I'm old enough to be your dad and I've been in blockchain long enough to have been very involved in infamous The DAO (Genesis). Always had interest in Ethermint, so I've been lurking/following since launch with  fascination, amusement, frustration, and now concern.

I had a great time chuckling and watching all you knuckleheads wrestle over governance for the past few months, but after [seeing this comedic piece](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/8545-preproposal-restructure-dao-introducing-councils) by "Phil", I knew it was time to step in as the road he suggests is a dangerous road. Young blood, your intentions are good, probably. But you and that fuckin' weird Evmos volunteer group (btw, they creep me the fuck out - convinced they're some sick Russian AIs) need to stop trying to force your agenda of this perfect fuckin organization that you are trying to create. It's not possible. Follow the footsteps and learn from DAOs that have already succeeded. Now is not the time to daydream your little fantasies and experiment with completely ridiculous governance structures and hope it works. Not only is that outright dangerous for the network in terms of security, but goddamn, I think people are expecting initiatives ASAP, not in three years.

The ECP props show careful research and consideration that went into them. I know because when we first started we had absolutely no references to use to our advantage. From what I see, the strategic goals are achievable, relatively easily believe it or not. Much of the base contracts are forkable right now, for fucks sake, and its important to note that the initiatives proposed are obviously a mix of inspirations from the successes of existing DAOs that took the much riskier but needed route of ideation, experimentation, and creation of everything from scratch. We've made a lot of mistakes along the way so that you don't have to make the same ones. Don't recreate the wheel.

**To the community: **

Let the gov folks do their fuckin' jobs. It only benefits you. Their insecurities lead them to title themselves as high and mighty COUNCIL MEMBERS... _**"ohhhhhm, so powerful, they must be, like, really important or something"**_  ...who the fuck cares what their self-assigned titles are? They've made it clear that they are intending to put the treasury under the control of a governance smart contract. What are they going to do, hit us with some _suuuper_ scary proposals? This heightened level of paranoia... must be a Cosmos thing.

And all this talk about how these guys "self-appointed themselves in a massive power grab conspiracy to control the network" needs to be put to rest. The way I see it, they worked for you for 6 months. Nothing ever came out that seemed bad intentioned. Every week, without fail, the "council" meetings with the core team has shown legitimate concerns and have shown their genuine care for growing the network. Adonis referred to them as Council, it was clear that they led the Evmos Governance, and not a single person objected or questioned. That's not self-appointment fellas. That's recognition. 

All good right? _**COUNCIL, YALL KEEP WORKING HARD, YALL DOING GREAT!**_  **ZERO** talk of centralization, **ZERO** mentions of self-appointment, **ZERO** problems. Then they ask for funding because humans, teams, projects, initiatives - guess what - they all need funding like the real world _**GASPPPP**_ who would've known!? 

Now all of a sudden their work is atrocious, they're greedy, they're trying to take over the network, <insert whatever conspiracy bullshit yall think of next>, because they ask for funding that mostly was to ultimately going **BACK INTO** the community ANYWAYS. _How can we trust them with the treasury?! They can't be trusted! _

Fellas, you gave them FULL CONTROL of several multisigs funded by communitypool with no questions asked, and if my calculations are right, those wallets were worth $8-10 million at the time... seriously, go look at all the incentive props that passed. If their intentions were to run off with money and power they couldve done so, cause you dumbnuts failed to check that proper multisigs configurations were set. But anyways, we trust them to control that much when its for **other** projects, but when its for projects meant for **us** to grow and improve **our** token economics, suddenly _**THEY CAN'T BE TRUSTED**_ 

Wheres the logic in that? Fuck outta here with that bullshit. 

_But their pays are too high! They have vesting contracts! More Evmos going to these evil monsters!_

Have none of you worked at a decent company before? Do y'all work minimum wage jobs (nothin' wrong with that young bloods, I did too most of my teens and early 20s, but it would explain a lot on why your panties are all tied up over the numbers). The base salaries are LAUGHABLE for the work they are doing. Whether you like it or not, through the past 6 months they have solidified themselves as the founding "CEO, CFO, COO, C-Level exec-type" roles within the DAO. Which is not necessarily a bad thing. And its good to see that they are uncomfortable with the status quo and are working to decentralize the DAO. 

 Their responsibilities from what I can tell are a fuckton and range from: 

- giving the DAO vision and a sense of direction (aka LEADERSHIP) that the community can rally behind
- setting up subdaos, payment structures, training cosmos DAO virgins, etc. (aka MANAGEMENT, OPERATIONS, HR)
- identifying the huge holes in the way incentives are being given out and designing complex programs that are more beneficial to the community and network (aka FINANCIAL/TOKEN ECONOMICS ENGINEERING)
- doubling down on progressive decentralization with a proposal in the works that would decentralize the network's flow of pool money i.e. incentives and grants through a dao platform/dashboard with a gauge and stake system (pretty sure that's what they are aiming for, AFAIK. That's PROTOCOL ENGINEERING AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT)
- helping projects and teams through governance and even with helping EDIT AND WRITE proposals (?!), while moderating the community social channels (jesus, thats EDITOR, ADVISOR, AND FUCKIN CUSTOMER SUPPORT LOL 🤣)

Let that sink in, ya cucks. _**They essentially are the DAO**_ and there's NO ONE to blame but yourselves. **YOU let that happen**. No one stepped up to help them AFAIK, no one actively tried to start community initiatives to help, and as much as you hate to admit it, Evmos governance wouldn't exist as we know it today without them. There probably be no community-led incentive programs leaving us with a network-wide TVL of practically zero, proposal creation would have no formalized process, and the DAO would solely exist as a front for the Evmos Foundation. 

I'd say my observational skills have improved quite drastically over the years, with involvement in all kinds of DAOs, working with bullshitters, trying to keep up with go-getters, and dealing with people who mean well, but ultimately are a huge pain in the ass for governance. It's obvious to me why LPX was in such as rush to get the subDAO framework out. _**They're fuckin overloaded with work,**_ but they have huge ambitions they want for the network. 


My quick observations into the initial three council members... (all assumptions and mini-detective work, dont fuckin quote me on this)

LPX is a go-getter type. Sometimes too ambitious for their own good, but ultimately brings huge value to a DAO. LPX is obviously "leading" the DAO with a "CEO and CTO" type role. That's also the vibe I get from Adonis during gov meetings I've attended, as well as his CW posts.  He leads the governance workstream but hates to admit it. You can bet your ass I looked into his history as well, he may be pseudo-anon, but huge amounts of paper trail get left behind in the pseudo-anon world. I will respect his privacy, as I fuckin'  expect everyone to respect mine, so I wont go into much details. To the best of my judgement, from my limited research, I feel fairly confident as his proposals and ideas are coming from actual experience and mentorship with great organizations and leaders. He is also fairly well connected to many Ethereum DAOs and protocols.

Benny seems to have stepped into a CFO and Communications type role. Seems very competent in traditional finances, accounting, and forecasting. I'd say he's responsible for all the numbers behind incentive proposals, but not too certain about his level of DeFi experience. Benny was comparatively much more difficult to find a trail, but if I had to take a guess, he's definitely working in the trad-fi sector. He is also more vocal than lpx when it comes to criticism. LPX either has a superiority complex that makes him not give a fuck about answering stupid ass questions and comments (eventually everyone in governance work will begin to develop this, stay sharp), or hes legitimately so overwhelmed or distracted with other work. While Benny is more vocal, but he doesnt seem comfortable or confident. Either way, I feel much better knowing that there is a finance savvy member member to assist the others. 

These two are most likely taking paycuts compared to what they could be making elsewhere. Anyone who says otherwise is either delusional, still in high school, live in an underdeveloped nation, is incapable of English comprehension on a higher level, or live on a farm.

Yes, yes, I know, I read it many times, Cosmos DAOs dont pay their contributors as well as real DAOs. Well thats a fuckin shame in my view, and its no wonder all the DAO talent are hanging out in Ethereum.

And yes, I know I didnt analyze GV.... to be honest I don't know what the fuck he does besides post a bunch of props.  I would like to learn more about what GV does and perhaps be givin more responsibilities if he is to take the same pay as benny. But then again, if the Council was more fuckin transparent we wouldnt be here right now with me so dumbfounded with with everything that I have to baby feed y'all kids on the proposal intent from the views of a veteran, the context around it, and the uncomfortable truth. (TBF: full transparency  is also a nearly impossible goal like full decentralization and autonomy)

While on the topic of compensation, those against vesting also have never worked for a company of any value in an important role. It's there to motivate leaders to deliver with raised expectations and accountability, and to dissuade key members and talent from leaving in the middle of a project. In my book, if any contributor is still sittin contributing to Evmos more than 4 years without being voted off or losing interest in the Evmos Ecosystem, then fuck, they deserve to be crowned as  EVMOS GODS. Is it wrong for DAO contributors to be rewarded for dedication and (presumed) success? 

Enough is enough, while I initially enjoyed watching it unfold, y'all need to stop with this bullshit and focus on the real issues at hand. The ECP props may not be perfect, but at least they have solid plans and strategies that are being placed and developed. The other proposal is just an abstract, untested idea with no feasible way for execution. I am warning you, learn from the mistakes we made when we just began to experiment with smart contracts. LPX is correct in his previous posts, there is a very legitimate and valid reason why DAOs take the route of progressive decentralization. Radical ideas like Phil's may sound interesting in theory, but they must be implemented in painstakingly slow incremental steps, or you too can make a $70 million mistake. 

It's honestly heartening to see the Governance Council still serving the community after all the shit coming out of misinformed mouths, and I wouldn't be surprised if they left yall to pick up the pieces and watch nothing get done. The type of shit I see on discord, telegram, here, jesus christ folks. Maybe cause I'm older I'm not used to this much shitposting, but you guys need to stop gobbling up that shit up like its xannie bars. Negativity, fake assumptions, conspiracies, paranoia. Fuck outta here with that shit, and go give the Council a hug and an apology, cause believe it or not they care more about you than the core team or the foundation. It's one of the many byproducts of a DAO that is well documented in the field of social, organizational, and economic studies. (don't get me wrong, core team probably loves you too, just not as much as community leaders 😉)

Validators and core team members, right now is when they need your vocal (and emotiona) support the most, working for a DAO does not suddenly make you non-human. Very disappointed to see very little of that. Culture is hard to grow, and everyone needs to play a part. From what I am witnessing, those Russian AI Volunteer Group are one of the absolute worst group of scum that can actually tear down entire communities. Don't let them divide you. DAO's are still made of humans (for now at least), and you mustn't forget that - the community should be fun to chat with, intellectual and constructive in nature, supportive and kind, etc etc. Some of my absolute best friends are fellow DAO members that I've worked with, yelled at, cried with, shitpost unfunny memes with, etc. Some of my best memories in life come from DAO origins. If you're not enjoying yourselves, you're not doing it right. And right now, that's the vibe I am getting.

Stop fighting amongst yourselves and come together to move the ecosystem forward. And Phil, I know I've been harsh, but you are absolutely playing with fire. Work with the Governance Council, don't divide it. The rejection of a proposal does not mean that the Evmos Community does not support the Governance Council, nor does it mean that the previous ECP is invalidated.

{"timestamp":"2022-12-21T18:48:13.089Z","author":"{"_judgements":{},"_isOnchain":false,"_isCouncillor":false,"_isValidator":false,"_isEmpty":false,"_isNameInvalid":false,"chain":"evmos","address":"evmos14ck5f7v3d99j3sh4kylq8g2dqkhhfw47cxq2yj","_initialized":true,"_name":"what_yall_smoking","_headline":"shit must be dank","_bio":"too old to be here yellin at kids. let me lurk in peace for fucks sake","_lastActive":"2022-12-21T14:58:09.444Z"}","body":"I'm too old to be spending energy on publicly shaming everyone for shit like this, but I felt the need to defend the "Governance Council" after lurking for months and being amused at all the shit that unfolds in Cosmos. I'm old enough to be your dad and I've been in blockchain long enough to have been very involved in infamous The DAO (Genesis). Always had interest in Ethermint, so I've been lurking/following since launch with  fascination, amusement, frustration, and now concern.

I had a great time chuckling and watching all you knuckleheads wrestle over governance for the past few months, but after [seeing this comedic piece](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/8545-preproposal-restructure-dao-introducing-councils) by "Phil", I knew it was time to step in as the road he suggests is a dangerous road. Young blood, your intentions are good, probably. But you and that fuckin' weird Evmos volunteer group (btw, they creep me the fuck out - convinced they're some sick Russian AIs) need to stop trying to force your agenda of this perfect fuckin organization that you are trying to create. It's not possible. Follow the footsteps and learn from DAOs that have already succeeded. Now is not the time to daydream your little fantasies and experiment with completely ridiculous governance structures and hope it works. Not only is that outright dangerous for the network in terms of security, but goddamn, I think people are expecting initiatives ASAP, not in three years.

The ECP props show careful research and consideration that went into them. I know because when we first started we had absolutely no references to use to our advantage. From what I see, the strategic goals are achievable, relatively easily believe it or not. Much of the base contracts are forkable right now, for fucks sake, and its important to note that the initiatives proposed are obviously a mix of inspirations from the successes of existing DAOs that took the much riskier but needed route of ideation, experimentation, and creation of everything from scratch. We've made a lot of mistakes along the way so that you don't have to make the same ones. Don't recreate the wheel.

**To the community: **

Let the gov folks do their fuckin' jobs. It only benefits you. Their insecurities lead them to title themselves as high and mighty COUNCIL MEMBERS... _**"ohhhhhm, so powerful, they must be, like, really important or something"**_  ...who the fuck cares what their self-assigned titles are? They've made it clear that they are intending to put the treasury under the control of a governance smart contract. What are they going to do, hit us with some _suuuper_ scary proposals? This heightened level of paranoia... must be a Cosmos thing.

And all this talk about how these guys "self-appointed themselves in a massive power grab conspiracy to control the network" needs to be put to rest. The way I see it, they worked for you for 6 months. Nothing ever came out that seemed bad intentioned. Every week, without fail, the "council" meetings with the core team has shown legitimate concerns and have shown their genuine care for growing the network. Adonis referred to them as Council, it was clear that they led the Evmos Governance, and not a single person objected or questioned. That's not self-appointment fellas. That's recognition. 

All good right? _**COUNCIL, YALL KEEP WORKING HARD, YALL DOING GREAT!**_  **ZERO** talk of centralization, **ZERO** mentions of self-appointment, **ZERO** problems. Then they ask for funding because humans, teams, projects, initiatives - guess what - they all need funding like the real world _**GASPPPP**_ who would've known!? 

Now all of a sudden their work is atrocious, they're greedy, they're trying to take over the network, <insert whatever conspiracy bullshit yall think of next>, because they ask for funding that mostly was to ultimately going **BACK INTO** the community ANYWAYS. _How can we trust them with the treasury?! They can't be trusted! _

Fellas, you gave them FULL CONTROL of several multisigs funded by communitypool with no questions asked, and if my calculations are right, those wallets were worth $8-10 million at the time... seriously, go look at all the incentive props that passed. If their intentions were to run off with money and power they couldve done so, cause you dumbnuts failed to check that proper multisigs configurations were set. But anyways, we trust them to control that much when its for **other** projects, but when its for projects meant for **us** to grow and improve **our** token economics, suddenly _**THEY CAN'T BE TRUSTED**_ 

Wheres the logic in that? Fuck outta here with that bullshit. 

_But their pays are too high! They have vesting contracts! More Evmos going to these evil monsters!_

Have none of you worked at a decent company before? Do y'all work minimum wage jobs (nothin' wrong with that young bloods, I did too most of my teens and early 20s, but it would explain a lot on why your panties are all tied up over the numbers). The base salaries are LAUGHABLE for the work they are doing. Whether you like it or not, through the past 6 months they have solidified themselves as the founding "CEO, CFO, COO, C-Level exec-type" roles within the DAO. Which is not necessarily a bad thing. And its good to see that they are uncomfortable with the status quo and are working to decentralize the DAO. 

 Their responsibilities from what I can tell are a fuckton and range from: 

- giving the DAO vision and a sense of direction (aka LEADERSHIP) that the community can rally behind
- setting up subdaos, payment structures, training cosmos DAO virgins, etc. (aka MANAGEMENT, OPERATIONS, HR)
- identifying the huge holes in the way incentives are being given out and designing complex programs that are more beneficial to the community and network (aka FINANCIAL/TOKEN ECONOMICS ENGINEERING)
- doubling down on progressive decentralization with a proposal in the works that would decentralize the network's flow of pool money i.e. incentives and grants through a dao platform/dashboard with a gauge and stake system (pretty sure that's what they are aiming for, AFAIK. That's PROTOCOL ENGINEERING AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT)
- helping projects and teams through governance and even with helping EDIT AND WRITE proposals (?!), while moderating the community social channels (jesus, thats EDITOR, ADVISOR, AND FUCKIN CUSTOMER SUPPORT LOL 🤣)

Let that sink in, ya cucks. _**They essentially are the DAO**_ and there's NO ONE to blame but yourselves. **YOU let that happen**. No one stepped up to help them AFAIK, no one actively tried to start community initiatives to help, and as much as you hate to admit it, Evmos governance wouldn't exist as we know it today without them. There probably be no community-led incentive programs leaving us with a network-wide TVL of practically zero, proposal creation would have no formalized process, and the DAO would solely exist as a front for the Evmos Foundation. 

I'd say my observational skills have improved quite drastically over the years, with involvement in all kinds of DAOs, working with bullshitters, trying to keep up with go-getters, and dealing with people who mean well, but ultimately are a huge pain in the ass for governance. It's obvious to me why LPX was in such as rush to get the subDAO framework out. _**They're fuckin overloaded with work,**_ but they have huge ambitions they want for the network. 


My quick observations into the initial three council members... (all assumptions and mini-detective work, dont fuckin quote me on this)

LPX is a go-getter type. Sometimes too ambitious for their own good, but ultimately brings huge value to a DAO. LPX is obviously "leading" the DAO with a "CEO and CTO" type role. That's also the vibe I get from Adonis during gov meetings I've attended, as well as his CW posts.  He leads the governance workstream but hates to admit it. You can bet your ass I looked into his history as well, he may be pseudo-anon, but huge amounts of paper trail get left behind in the pseudo-anon world. I will respect his privacy, as I fuckin'  expect everyone to respect mine, so I wont go into much details. To the best of my judgement, from my limited research, I feel fairly confident as his proposals and ideas are coming from actual experience and mentorship with great organizations and leaders. He is also fairly well connected to many Ethereum DAOs and protocols.

Benny seems to have stepped into a CFO and Communications type role. Seems very competent in traditional finances, accounting, and forecasting. I'd say he's responsible for all the numbers behind incentive proposals, but not too certain about his level of DeFi experience. Benny was comparatively much more difficult to find a trail, but if I had to take a guess, he's definitely working in the trad-fi sector. He is also more vocal than lpx when it comes to criticism. LPX either has a superiority complex that makes him not give a fuck about answering stupid ass questions and comments (eventually everyone in governance work will begin to develop this, stay sharp), or hes legitimately so overwhelmed or distracted with other work. While Benny is more vocal, but he doesnt seem comfortable or confident. Either way, I feel much better knowing that there is a finance savvy member member to assist the others. 

These two are most likely taking paycuts compared to what they could be making elsewhere. Anyone who says otherwise is either delusional, still in high school, live in an underdeveloped nation, is incapable of English comprehension on a higher level, or live on a farm.

Yes, yes, I know, I read it many times, Cosmos DAOs dont pay their contributors as well as real DAOs. Well thats a fuckin shame in my view, and its no wonder all the DAO talent are hanging out in Ethereum.

And yes, I know I didnt analyze GV.... to be honest I don't know what the fuck he does besides post a bunch of props.  I would like to learn more about what GV does and perhaps be givin more responsibilities if he is to take the same pay as benny. But then again, if the Council was more fuckin transparent we wouldnt be here right now with me so dumbfounded with with everything that I have to baby feed y'all kids on the proposal intent from the views of a veteran, the context around it, and the uncomfortable truth. (TBF: full transparency  is also a nearly impossible goal like full decentralization and autonomy)

While on the topic of compensation, those against vesting also have never worked for a company of any value in an important role. It's one of the many byproducts of a DAO that is well documented in the field of social, organizational, and economic studies. (don't get me wrong, core team probably loves you too, just not as much as community leaders 😉)

Validators and core team members, right now is when they need your vocal (and emotiona) support the most, working for a DAO does not suddenly make you non-human. Very disappointed to see very little of that. Culture is hard to grow, and everyone needs to play a part. result.title: [Update: CANCELED] Repayment of effort for Informal Evmos Governance Workstream
result.plaintext:
**[UPDATE] The self-appointed Evmos DAO members decided to go ahead and aggregate their retroactive payment ask with creating the official positions for the Evmos DAO and with proposing themselves in those official positions, all in one proposal that was rejected [https://www.mintscan.io/evmos/proposals/86](https://www.mintscan.io/evmos/proposals/86), despite warnings from the community. The current proposal was made in good faith, to help both them and the chain, by clarifying intent, to determine the best course of action. Considering how it was received by LPX, Benny Lava and GV, I no longer have reasons to fight for this cause.**

In the attempt to help the creation of Evmos DAO, I am proposing to the Evmos Community the disjoining of the proposal for [[ECP-2A] Formalizing and Funding the Governance Council Workstream - UPDATED](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/7743-ecp2a-formalizing-and-funding-the-governance-council-workstream-updated)
Into:
1. A proposal for repayment of effort for LPX, Benny Lava, GV
2. The proposal for creating the Workstream as an organization, together with the required offices
3. One or more proposals for filling the offices with the correct personnel.

This present proposal is the first in the sequence.
We would recognize the hard-working people of the informal Workstream as follows:

## 1. LPX

- Discord username: @LPX | Evmos DAO#3224
- Commonwealth: https://commonwealth.im/evmos/account/evmos1898ukgfpkxpd79kxk2tz3r9wdvl406cwfzeppf?base=evmos

Retroactive Payment: ~~15,000~~ 22,500 EVMOS for the past 6 months of contributions

## 2. Benny Lava

- Discord username: @bennylava#4485
- Commonwealth: https://commonwealth.im/evmos/account/evmos1u0qpyh04ufyyt6q0vqj7pjwk6k0j2mjm353zsj?base=evmos

Retroactive Payment: ~~12,500~~ 18,750 EVMOS for the past 6 months of contributions

## 3. GV

- Discord username: @creeea#8635 (GV | Swiss Staking)
- Commonwealth: https://commonwealth.im/evmos/account/evmos1q2r0ljt3zd59fnxvk6amfdddqg7y806ghhxkct?base=evmos

Retroactive Payment: ~~7,500~~ 11,250 EVMOS for the past 6 months of contributions

## TOTAL: ~~35,000~~ 52,500 $EVMOS

## Distribution

LPX, Benny Lava, and GV should each make their Evmos address public.
The funds will go to a multisig, in escrow - TBD.


### Discussions

The retroactive payment values were taken from the last (updated) draft and multiplied by 1.5, to account for $EVMOS value loss (discussed in this Commonwealth thread).

- last draft version: [[ECP-2A] Formalizing and Funding the Governance Council Workstream - UPDATED](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/7743-ecp2a-formalizing-and-funding-the-governance-council-workstream-updated)
- initial discussion: [[ECP-2A] Formalizing and Funding the Governance Council Workstream](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/7444-ecp2a-formalizing-and-funding-the-governance-council-workstream)
- [Evmos DAO Creation Discussion](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/7782-evmos-dao-creation-discussion)

### Proposal Author

Loredana Cirstea. I was elected by vote in the Evmos Interchain Office [Evmos Governance proposal #45](https://www.mintscan.io/evmos/proposals/45), I have been contributing to core development for Evmos and Ethermint (code, prototypes, innovations, video demos, governance, wallet) as a volunteer from The Laurel Project (unpaid, self-funded, from the heart), with more than 100h/week. Detailed contributions [here](https://evolve.provable.dev/). Grassroots investor.

result.title: %5BECP-2A%5D%20Formalizing%20and%20Funding%20the%20Governance%20Council%20Workstream%20-%20UPDATED
result.plaintext:
# ECP-2A: Formalizing and Funding the Governance Council Workstream

---

**Authors:** 

- LPX, Evmos DAO Governance Council
- GV, Evmos DAO Governance Council
- Benny Lava, Evmos DAO Governance Council

**Summary**: The Governance Workstream that has been serving the Evmos DAO and the Community is officially requesting formalization by funding. 

### **Workstream Introduction**

Decentralized governance is a double-edged sword with constant challenges to overcome and is often burdened with inefficient processes. It is also the beauty and soul of a DAO, with the ethos of decentralization and equality at the very core. The Governance Council exists and operates as a neutral party with allegiances only to the Evmos network and the guiding values of the Evmos Constitution. While the workstream is tasked with various duties, our mandate is simple: to facilitate and protect the integrity of Evmos' governance processes and, to the best of our ability, create a fair and transparent environment in which the network and the community can prosper and thrive.  

**Mission**: Protect, improve, and serve the Evmos network and community with neutrality and transparency.

**Vision**: To see Evmos DAO evolve into a fully decentralized and self-sustainable organization that is capable of propelling the growth of the network.

**Values:** Progressive Decentralization, Continuous Improvement, Hybrid-Governance

### Primary Duties (Ongoing & Planned)

**A. Governance Framework Improvement & Implementation**

The Evmos Governance Framework serves to empower each member of the community by providing clear and standardized methods of interacting with the wider DAO, thereby defining its future shape and trajectory. It is crucial that we strive to continuously improve our processes. 

 - The Constitution must be completed and amended as committed in Proposal 51, which ratified the Interim Constitution of Evmos DAO.
 - Governance proposals that have been passed by the community must be implemented and enforced, as long as they adhere to the Guiding Principles of our Constitution.
 - We must be diligent in listening to the community's feedback on governance pain-points, shortcomings, and inefficiencies. 
 - We must strive to fix or improve inefficiencies and shortcomings when a viable plan is ideated or presented.
 - We must continue our research and observations into other DAOs and remain up to date with evolving DAO philosophies, tools, and scientific research.

**B. Continuous Efforts in Increasing Governance Participation & Engagement**

The strength of our governance relates directly to the participation levels in both on-chain and off-chain governance. Decisions and proposals can only be as well-rounded and well-defined as the number of participants that played a role in contributing to the ideation and feedback process. Similarly, a decision or proposal is only as credible as the consensus surrounding it. 

 - The Governance Council has been aiming and will continue to promote and increase engagement by stakeholders in all aspects of the governance processes.
 - The Governance Council will work to improve and provide access to the resources necessary to participate in the governance process — for all members of the community.
 - The Governance Council should be in constant engagement with the community, in as many mediums as possible.

**C. Facilitating Communications and the Flow of Information**

Effective communication is a crucial strategy that must be used by the Governance Workstream. Transparent and effective governance requires an effective, reliable, and unbiased communications strategy. Without communication and information flow, it is extremely difficult to facilitate an effective and efficient governance.

 - The Governance Council will work to improve and create easier access to the resources necessary to understand and stay up-to-date in our governance — for all members of the community.
 - The Governance Council must establish a more consistent, high-quality information feed of all issues and proposals for the community at large to digest.
 - The Governance Council, when requested by the community, will act as a liaison to the Evmos Foundation and attempt to seek information and clarity into concerns or issues brought up. 
 - The Governance Council will remain in constant communication with the Foundation to ensure the alignment of the goals of the DAO, the community, and the core members. 
 - The Governance Council will work with the Community Moderation & Support team in the ideation of better communication initiatives, as well as pinpointing areas that are in need of improvements or clarifications.
 - The Governance Council will host community meetings, project introductions, and public forums when requested.
 - The Governance Council will continue to attend, participate in, and — if requested — take on the responsibility of hosting the weekly Governance meetings on Discord

**D. Governance and Proposal Assistance and Feedback**

 - The Governance Workstream will continue to provide assistance to individuals, teams, and projects that are seeking to submit a proposal. This includes all phases, from pre-Commonwealth ideation to the final on-chain submission, assuming that all procedures are being followed properly and in good faith. Our assistance in drafting proposals should not be seen as an endorsement or guarantee.
 - The Governance Workstream will always strive to voice all thoughts on an issue or proposal from a neutral, rational point of view.
 - The Governance Council will continue to work on improving governance documentation and begin building tools and resources for a more effective, transparent, and user-friendly governance.

**E.** **Onboarding of New Workstreams and sub-DAOs**

The Governance Council will assist in the creation of new workstreams. When focusing on accelerating the progress of the DAO, the goal is to grow horizontally via more sub-DAOs (vs. growing vertically). Through more sub-DAOs, the entire org can increase the number of teams trying new approaches to solving and innovating on existing problems and focuses while maintaining the same level of meta-organizational admin/overhead required to run. Our general stance on workstream or funding proposals will be:

 - Support funding proposals that presents a decent chance of driving forward KPIs
 - Explore funding proposals that may have a chance of bringing value and test the waters
 - Support the allocation of more resources to sub-DAOs that are producing results and are looking to expand
 - Investigate and potentially look into de-funding teams or initiatives that are not producing any results 

**F. Protocol & Cross-Chain Collaboration**

 - The Governance Council will continue to engage with and act as a community liaison with protocols and projects seeking to build or collaborate with Evmos.
 - The Governance Council will continue to engage in outreach to projects and protocols for potential collaborative initiatives that could be beneficial to the overall Evmos ecosystem.


**G. Evmos DAO’s Treasury Management, Diversification, & Growth**

**Phase 1**

 - The Governance Council will deploy a Gnosis Safe multi-sig contract to be used as Evmos DAO’s Liquid Treasury.
 - This contract will act as the DAO's liquid treasury for various purposes, including contributor and bounty rewards, liquidity and incentive programs, asset diversification, and minor expenses that do not warrant its own proposal.
 - The Governance Council will make two treasury funding requests. The initial request will fund the development of the projects detailed in ECP-3.

**Phase 2**

- ECP-3 will be formally proposed when the projects detailed are close to completion, and receives the approval of the Evmos Community.

### Projects and Initiatives (Ongoing & Planned)

**A. Liquidity Incentives Programs 2.0** (In Progress)

Although we have begun the "manual" Liquidity Incentives Program with our recent "Kickstart Evmos DeFi" proposal, our goal is to ultimately have this process determined by the community on a merit or milestone-based system.

In order to achieve this in a truly transparent and permissionless way, an Off-Chain Governance Framework is required. 

**(More info in ECP-3)**

**B. Off-Chain Community Governance** (In Progress)

Off-chain governance is often required for decisions in which the ultimate result is unknown and cannot be derived from on-chain data, thus requiring some human input. These decisions should be made with the mission, vision and goals of the DAO in mind.

> DAOs work best when the governance burden related to curation, security, and risk can be reduced faster than the natural increase in coordination costs that accompanies the need to have members involved in voting on every decision made. - Tarun Chitra

Optimizing for the right people to participate in governance processes is an ever-evolving discussion in governance circles today. It may not be pragmatic to assume that all voters should participate in every governance decision. Participating in governance is a lot of work—reading and digesting a proposal, providing feedback for discussion and going to vote can be mentally fatiguing. In addition, many do not have the subject matter expertise or desire to participate in proposals outside of their domain. 

Off-Chain governance, **in the context of Evmos DAO and the Cosmos ecosystem,** in simplified terms, can be explained as governance decisions that do not need to commence a network-wide vote through the utilization of the Cosmos SDKs \`gov\` module.

Off-Chain governance, **in the context of Decentralized Governance and DAOs in the Ethereum ecosystem**, can be explained as all governance decisions that utilize decentralized data and DID protocols like Ceramic and IPFS to allow for gas-free voting, encouraging the participation of more token holders.

DAO operations will likely be governed by contracts and tooling that are battle-tested and available on the EVM side of the chain. This opens up a new realm of possibilities for governance, trustless contracts, incentive alignment, and community collaboration.

While this is a particularly complex and interesting topic, we do not want to dwell in contemplation more than needed nor do we want to be married to one idea or framework. Our off-chain governance styling, processes, and direction will likely evolve over time, as is common with all DAOs, new and old. (Reference: [Gall’s Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Gall\_(author)#Gall's_law))

High-priority items needed for off-chain governance are currently under research and in experimentation phases in some cases; these include: 

 - Different Voting Mechanisms
 - The Alignment of Incentives
 - Contracts, Protocols, and DAO Toolings
 - Risk Reduction Efforts
 - (More in ECP-3)

**C. Perpetual Bounty Fund** (In Progress)

The Perpetual Bounty Fund is a perpetual, self-replenishing bounty fund that is designed to minimize community spending while helping with network decentralization efforts.

The concept of a perpetual bounty fund is very straightforward and the establishment of the fund would only require a one-time spend request from the community pool.

 1. The initial funds are delegated to a distributed set of validators that are in the mid-low ranking.
 2. The authz module from Cosmos SDK is utilized to re-stake a minimum “maintenance” amount (to account for decreasing APY rates)
 3. Utilizing authz, the remainder of the rewards are sent to a multisig wallet.
 4. The daily rewards are then utilized to fund bounty programs for the community.

When compared to a normal community pool budget request, this model would A) take the initial funding amount out of the unbonded circulating supply; B) align with the community goals of striving towards more decentralization; C) provide a steady stream of a workable budget to be bountied out responsibly and methodically.

**D. Governance Engagement Initiatives** (In Research)

The Governance Council is constantly looking into ideas or tools that may help with participation rate pre-voting on chain.

We strongly believe that the best way to reduce failed proposals is to address all community concerns during the early stages of a proposal. Increased participation in these early stage proposals would greatly benefit Evmos governance, and is an initiative we are taking seriously.

Some projects we are strongly considering in this area are a much comprehensive governance dashboard, engagement tracking, and more.

**E. Proposal Summary and Risk Assessment Reports** (Planned)

The Governance Council is looking to provide proposal summaries, context, and our risk assessments for all proposals that go on chain.

Talks of potentially integrating these reports and other valuable metadata around a proposal into popular block explorers have been initiated and may be considered.

**F. Deployment of Public Goods and Services** (In Progress)

The Governance Council is currently looking into public goods and infrastructure that we believe is needed to:

 - Attract more projects and organizations to migrate to Evmos
 - Attract more developers to build on Evmos
 - Allow more flexibility and functionality in what’s possible via governance
 - Increase governance participation rate and the flow of information

Some projects that the Governance Council has initiated in this domain:

 - [Governance Issue Tracker](https://evmos.community)
 - [Evmos RPC Proxy](https://github.com/EvmosGov/evmos-rpc-proxy)
 - [Evmos Datahub](https://github.com/EvmosGov/evmos-datahub)
 - [Webmos React Bootstrapping Kit](https://github.com/EvmosGov/webmos)
 - Smart contracts for: token vesting, payment streaming, payment splits
 - [Dashboard for Vesting Contracts](https://github.com/EvmosGov/contributor-vesting-ui)

**G. Validator Fairness Initiative** (In Progress)

 - The VFI Group was created a few months back in an attempt to get consensus on a Code of Conduct for Validators.
 - Although currently at a stalemate, there has been great discussions and is now over 100 members strong. 
 - We must reach a consensus, as the Interim Constitution was proposed on the premise that these difficult but pressing issues would not be forgotten.

The Evmos DAO has been operating informally with Governance Initiatives since early June 2022, and was formally recognized by the Evmos Community when the Constitution was ratified on August 31st, 2022. While we realize that we have much work ahead of us, we humbly celebrate the achievements the workstream and DAO members have made thus far.

#### B. Research & Development Fund

As over 109 million tokens sit idly in the Community Pool, the DAO wishes to utilize a relatively small portion in its continued efforts to advance the Evmos ecosystem. As the main driving force in community-led growth of Evmos, we hope that the Community is able to see our vision in what is possible with a workable treasury.

ECP-3 (WIP) lays out our strategic and ambitious programs that will pave the path for a self-sustainable DAO with mechanisms designed to decentralize decision making, incentivize governance participation, and assist with network decentralization.

While most of the underlying research has been conducted, the implementation, development, auditing, and testing of the GOV ecosystem will require a considerable amount of resources. 

Our goal is to roll out each program detailed in ECP-3 in a modular basis with the veGOV and Liquidity Incentives Gauge program as first priority (target launch date of mid-late Q1 2023). We have already initiated discussions with developers and DAOs with experience in the creation of similar DeFi programs, and we fully intend to collaborate with and compensate for the assistance received. 

The R&D funding requests are rough estimates; unused funds will remain in the workstream treasury as reserves.

#### C. Ecosystem Bootstrap Fund

The Ecosystem Bootstrap Fund will be the pre-cursor to the eventual Perpetual Bounty Fund detailed in ECP-3. While the core concept of a self-replenishing fund through delegation is the same, the Bootstrap Fund will have to be manually managed until the deGOV program and Delegation Gauges are ready to be deployed. 

The Ecosytem Bootstrap Fund is currently seeded with a ~30K EVMOS grant from the Foundation.

The Governance Council is requesting **500,000 EVMOS** for the strengthening of the Ecosystem Bootstrap Fund. 300K will be delegated on the network, which equates to roughly 25,000 EVMOS / month that will be used for bounties and community initiatives. 100K will be kept in reserves for usage in micro-grants and liquidity bootstrapping assistance for new projects deploying on the Evmos network.


#### D. Treasury Diversification & Future Workstreams

The Governance Council is requesting **600,000 EVMOS** to be allocated for treasury diversification into stablecoins. The obtained stablecoins will be reserved for Workstream & subDAO members' compensation. 

Diversification methodology: we are currently exploring a DAO2DAO token-for-stable swap with Ethereum-based DAOs that are looking to diversify their revenue streams. This allows for the diversification of our treasury and the extension of our runway without creating sell-pressure of EVMOS in the open market. 

When an opportunity for a token-stable swap is not available at a moment when the Treasury is in need of stables, no more than 50K Evmos from the Diversification Fund can be sold on the open market per month.

---

**Authors:** 

- LPX, Evmos DAO Governance Council
- GV, Evmos DAO Governance Council
- Benny Lava, Evmos DAO Governance Council

**Summary**: The Governance Workstream that has been serving the Evmos DAO and the Community is officially requesting formalization by funding. 

### **Workstream Introduction**

Decentralized governance is a double-edged sword with constant challenges to overcome and is often burdened with inefficient processes. It is also the beauty and soul of a DAO, with the ethos of decentralization and equality at the very core. The Governance Council exists and operates as a neutral party with allegiances only to the Evmos network and the guiding values of the Evmos Constitution. While the workstream is tasked with various duties, our mandate is simple: to facilitate and protect the integrity of Evmos' governance processes and, to the best of our ability, create a fair and transparent environment in which the network and the community can prosper and thrive.  

**Mission**: Protect, improve, and serve the Evmos network and community with neutrality and transparency.

**Vision**: To see Evmos DAO evolve into a fully decentralized and self-sustainable organization that is capable of propelling the growth of the network.

**Values:** Progressive Decentralization, Continuous Improvement, Hybrid-Governance

### Primary Duties (Ongoing & Planned)

**A. Governance Framework Improvement & Implementation**

The Evmos Governance Framework serves to empower each member of the community by providing clear and standardized methods of interacting with the wider DAO, thereby defining its future shape and trajectory. It is crucial that we strive to continuously improve our processes. 

 - The Constitution must be completed and amended as committed in Proposal 51, which ratified the Interim Constitution of Evmos DAO.
 - Governance proposals that have been passed by the community must be implemented and enforced, as long as they adhere to the Guiding Principles of our Constitution.
 - We must be diligent in listening to the community's feedback on governance pain-points, shortcomings, and inefficiencies. 
 - We must strive to fix or improve inefficiencies and shortcomings when a viable plan is ideated or presented.
 - We must continue our research and observations into other DAOs and remain up to date with evolving DAO philosophies, tools, and scientific research.

**B. Continuous Efforts in Increasing Governance Participation & Engagement**

The strength of our governance relates directly to the participation levels in both on-chain and off-chain governance. Decisions and proposals can only be as well-rounded and well-defined as the number of participants that played a role in contributing to the ideation and feedback process. Similarly, a decision or proposal is only as credible as the consensus surrounding it. 

 - The Governance Council has been aiming and will continue to promote and increase engagement by stakeholders in all aspects of the governance processes.
 - The Governance Council will work to improve and provide access to the resources necessary to participate in the governance process — for all members of the community.
 - The Governance Council should be in constant engagement with the community, in as many mediums as possible.

**C. Facilitating Communications and the Flow of Information**

Effective communication is a crucial strategy that must be used by the Governance Workstream. Transparent and effective governance requires an effective, reliable, and unbiased communications strategy. Without communication and information flow, it is extremely difficult to facilitate an effective and efficient governance.

 - The Governance Council will work to improve and create easier access to the resources necessary to understand and stay up-to-date in our governance — for all members of the community.
 - The Governance Council must establish a more consistent, high-quality information feed of all issues and proposals for the community at large to digest.
 - The Governance Council, when requested by the community, will act as a liaison to the Evmos Foundation and attempt to seek information and clarity into concerns or issues brought up. 
 - The Governance Council will remain in constant communication with the Foundation to ensure the alignment of the goals of the DAO, the community, and the core members. 
 - The Governance Council will work with the Community Moderation & Support team in the ideation of better communication initiatives, as well as pinpointing areas that are in need of improvements or clarifications.
 - The Governance Council will host community meetings, project introductions, and public forums when requested.
 - The Governance Council will continue to attend, participate in, and — if requested — take on the responsibility of hosting the weekly Governance meetings on Discord

**D. Governance and Proposal Assistance and Feedback**

 - The Governance Workstream will continue to provide assistance to individuals, teams, and projects that are seeking to submit a proposal. This includes all phases, from pre-Commonwealth ideation to the final on-chain submission, assuming that all procedures are being followed properly and in good faith. Our assistance in drafting proposals should not be seen as an endorsement or guarantee.
 - The Governance Workstream will always strive to voice all thoughts on an issue or proposal from a neutral, rational point of view.
 - The Governance Council will continue to work on improving governance documentation and begin building tools and resources for a more effective, transparent, and user-friendly governance.

**E.** **Onboarding of New Workstreams and sub-DAOs**

The Governance Council will assist in the creation of new workstreams. When focusing on accelerating the progress of the DAO, the goal is to grow horizontally via more sub-DAOs (vs. growing vertically). Through more sub-DAOs, the entire org can increase the number of teams trying new approaches to solving and innovating on existing problems and focuses while maintaining the same level of meta-organizational admin/overhead required to run. Our general stance on workstream or funding proposals will be:

 - Support funding proposals that presents a decent chance of driving forward KPIs
 - Explore funding proposals that may have a chance of bringing value and test the waters
 - Support the allocation of more resources to sub-DAOs that are producing results and are looking to expand
 - Investigate and potentially look into de-funding teams or initiatives that are not producing any results 

**F. Protocol & Cross-Chain Collaboration**

 - The Governance Council will continue to engage with and act as a community liaison with protocols and projects seeking to build or collaborate with Evmos.
 - The Governance Council will continue to engage in outreach to projects and protocols for potential collaborative initiatives that could be beneficial to the overall Evmos ecosystem.


**G. Evmos DAO’s Treasury Management, Diversification, & Growth**

**Phase 1**

 - The Governance Council will deploy a Gnosis Safe multi-sig contract to be used as Evmos DAO’s Liquid Treasury.
 - This contract will act as the DAO's liquid treasury for various purposes, including contributor and bounty rewards, liquidity and incentive programs, asset diversification, and minor expenses that do not warrant its own proposal.
 - The Governance Council will make two treasury funding requests. The initial request will fund the development of the projects detailed in ECP-3.

**Phase 2**

- ECP-3 will be formally proposed when the projects detailed are close to completion, and receives the approval of the Evmos Community.

### Projects and Initiatives (Ongoing & Planned)

**A. Liquidity Incentives Programs 2.0** (In Progress)

Although we have begun the "manual" Liquidity Incentives Program with our recent "Kickstart Evmos DeFi" proposal, our goal is to ultimately have this process determined by the community on a merit or milestone-based system.

In order to achieve this in a truly transparent and permissionless way, an Off-Chain Governance Framework is required. 

**(More info in ECP-3)**

**B. Off-Chain Community Governance** (In Progress)

Off-chain governance is often required for decisions in which the ultimate result is unknown and cannot be derived from on-chain data, thus requiring some human input. These decisions should be made with the mission, vision and goals of the DAO in mind.

> DAOs work best when the governance burden related to curation, security, and risk can be reduced faster than the natural increase in coordination costs that accompanies the need to have members involved in voting on every decision made. - Tarun Chitra

Optimizing for the right people to participate in governance processes is an ever-evolving discussion in governance circles today. It may not be pragmatic to assume that all voters should participate in every governance decision. Participating in governance is a lot of work—reading and digesting a proposal, providing feedback for discussion and going to vote can be mentally fatiguing. In addition, many do not have the subject matter expertise or desire to participate in proposals outside of their domain. 

Off-Chain governance, **in the context of Evmos DAO and the Cosmos ecosystem,** in simplified terms, can be explained as governance decisions that do not need to commence a network-wide vote through the utilization of the Cosmos SDKs \`gov\` module.

Off-Chain governance, **in the context of Decentralized Governance and DAOs in the Ethereum ecosystem**, can be explained as all governance decisions that utilize decentralized data and DID protocols like Ceramic and IPFS to allow for gas-free voting, encouraging the participation of more token holders.

DAO operations will likely be governed by contracts and tooling that are battle-tested and available on the EVM side of the chain. This opens up a new realm of possibilities for governance, trustless contracts, incentive alignment, and community collaboration.

While this is a particularly complex and interesting topic, we do not want to dwell in contemplation more than needed nor do we want to be married to one idea or framework. Our off-chain governance styling, processes, and direction will likely evolve over time, as is common with all DAOs, new and old. (Reference: [Gall’s Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Gall\_(author)#Gall's_law))

High-priority items needed for off-chain governance are currently under research and in experimentation phases in some cases; these include: 

 - Different Voting Mechanisms
 - The Alignment of Incentives
 - Contracts, Protocols, and DAO Toolings
 - Risk Reduction Efforts
 - (More in ECP-3)

**C. Perpetual Bounty Fund** (In Progress)

The Perpetual Bounty Fund is a perpetual, self-replenishing bounty fund that is designed to minimize community spending while helping with network decentralization efforts.

The concept of a perpetual bounty fund is very straightforward and the establishment of the fund would only require a one-time spend request from the community pool.

 1. The initial funds are delegated to a distributed set of validators that are in the mid-low ranking.
 2. The authz module from Cosmos SDK is utilized to re-stake a minimum “maintenance” amount (to account for decreasing APY rates)
 3. Utilizing authz, the remainder of the rewards are sent to a multisig wallet.
 4. The daily rewards are then utilized to fund bounty programs for the community.

When compared to a normal community pool budget request, this model would A) take the initial funding amount out of the unbonded circulating supply; B) align with the community goals of striving towards more decentralization; C) provide a steady stream of a workable budget to be bountied out responsibly and methodically.

**D. Governance Engagement Initiatives** (In Research)

The Governance Council is constantly looking into ideas or tools that may help with participation rate pre-voting on chain.

We strongly believe that the best way to reduce failed proposals is to address all community concerns during the early stages of a proposal. Increased participation in these early stage proposals would greatly benefit Evmos governance, and is an initiative we are taking seriously.

Some projects we are strongly considering in this area are a much comprehensive governance dashboard, engagement tracking, and more.

**E. Proposal Summary and Risk Assessment Reports** (Planned)

The Governance Council is looking to provide proposal summaries, context, and our risk assessments for all proposals that go on chain.

Talks of potentially integrating these reports and other valuable metadata around a proposal into popular block explorers have been initiated and may be considered.

**F. Deployment of Public Goods and Services** (In Progress)

The Governance Council is currently looking into public goods and infrastructure that we believe is needed to:

 - Attract more projects and organizations to migrate to Evmos
 - Attract more developers to build on Evmos
 - Allow more flexibility and functionality in what’s possible via governance
 - Increase governance participation rate and the flow of information

Some projects that the Governance Council has initiated in this domain:

 - [Governance Issue Tracker](https://evmos.community)
 - [Evmos RPC Proxy](https://github.com/EvmosGov/evmos-rpc-proxy)
 - [Evmos Datahub](https://github.com/EvmosGov/evmos-datahub)
 - [Webmos React Bootstrapping Kit](https://github.com/EvmosGov/webmos)
 - Smart contracts for: token vesting, payment streaming, payment splits
 - [Dashboard for Vesting Contracts](https://github.com/EvmosGov/contributor-vesting-ui)

**G. Validator Fairness Initiative** (In Progress)

 - The VFI Group was created a few months back in an attempt to get consensus on a Code of Conduct for Validators.
 - Although currently at a stalemate, there has been great discussions and is now over 100 members strong. 
 - We must reach a consensus, as the Interim Constitution was proposed on the premise that these difficult but pressing issues would not be forgotten.   

### Progress Report and Achievements

The Evmos DAO has been operating informally with Governance Initiatives since early June 2022, and was formally recognized by the Evmos Community when the Constitution was ratified on August 31st, 2022. While we realize that we have much work ahead of us, we humbly celebrate the achievements the workstream and DAO members have made thus far.

**Evmos Community Proposals**

The Governance Council and DAO Contributors have assisted in, provided support to, or played a direct role in the proposals listed below.

| #   | Title                                                               | Role              |
| --- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------- |
| 27  | Evmos Get Momentum - $1m Evmos Developer Incentive Program Proposal | Feedback, Support |
| 31  | Grant Request to Sponsor EVMOS Public RPC by Pocket Network         | Feedback          |
| 34  | Extend Rektdrop Claims Period by 21 days                            | Direct            |
| 35  | Register ERC20 for Osmosis                                          | Direct            |

After posting the ["Passing a Community Proposal, Best Practices"](https://commonwealth.im/evmos/discussion/6022-passing-a-community-proposal-best-practices) guide, the Governance Workstream and DAO contributors assisted in passing **24 out of 25 proposals for a success rate of 96%.**

We are currently assisting in the facilitation and/or drafting of various additional proposals ranging from protocol onboarding to incentives programs.

**On-Chain Governance Participation**

Evmos on-chain governance participation rate is currently the highest among the top Cosmos chains (as of data pulled Oct. 8th 2022) and is barely managing to maintain an upwards trend. With a participation rate of almost 90%, the Governance Workstream will most likely be fighting to maintain the status quo, as we are almost at the ceiling.
